This data [MASK] has shed considerable light on dramatic inequalities in faculty training , placement , and scholarly productivity [ 6 , 19 , 20 ] .	set
But , this data [MASK] is only a single snapshot of an evolving and expanding system and hence offers few insights into the changing composition and diversity trends within these academic fields .	set
In some fields , yearly [MASK] on faculty numbers and composition are available in aggregate .	data
In computer science , the Computing Research [MASK] ( CRA ) documents trends in the employment of PhD recipients through the annual Taulbee survey of computing departments in North America ( cra.org/resources/taulbee-survey ) .	Association
Such [MASK] can provide valuable insight into trends and summary statistics on the scientific workforce but suffer from two key weaknesses .	surveys
First , [MASK] are subject to variable response rates and the misinterpretation of questions or sample frames , which can inject bias into fine - grained analyses [ 21 , 22 ] .	surveys
Second , aggregate [MASK] provides only a high - level view of a field , which can make it difficult to investigate causality [ 23 ] .	information
Here , [MASK] present a novel system , based on a topical web crawler , that can quickly and automatically assemble a full census of an academic field using digital data available on the public World Wide Web .	we
This [MASK] is efficient and accurate , and it can be adapted to any academic discipline and used for continuous collection .	system
The [MASK] is capable of collecting census data for an entire academic field in just a few hours using off - the - shelf computing hardware , a vast improvement over the roughly 1600 hours required to do this task by hand [ 19 ] .	system
By assembling an accurate census of an entire field from online information alone , this [MASK] will facilitate new research on the composition of academic fields by providing access to complete faculty listings , without having to rely on surveys or professional societies .	system
Finally , applied to many academic fields in parallel , the [MASK] can elucidate scientists  movement between different disciplines and relate those labor flows to scientific advances .	system
In short , many important research [MASK] will benefit from the availability of accurate and frequently - recollected census data .	questions
[MASK] begin by detailing the design and implementation of our web crawler framework .	We
Next , [MASK] present the results of our work in two sections .	we
The [MASK] demonstrates the validity and utility of the crawler by collecting census data for the field of computer science and comparing it to a hand - curated census , collected in 2011 [ 19 ] .	first
The [MASK] provides an example of the type of research enabled by our system and uses the 2011 and 2017 censuses to investigate the  leaky pipeline  problem in faculty retention .	second
Throughout the second half of the 20th century , [MASK] have witnessed the return of institutions to economic analysis .	we
The [MASK] of the Nobel Prize in Economics to its main representatives ( Douglass North , Ronald Coase , Oliver Williamson , and Elinor Ostrom ) has contributed to its greater recognition .	awarding
The two main [MASK] of this economic approach are the concepts of transaction costs and institutions , analyzed by Coase and North , respectively .	notions
[MASK] [ 13 , 14 ] argues that economic transactions involve costs , and where these costs outweigh the gains , the exchange will not take place .	Coase
For its part , [MASK] defined the institutions as the  rules of the game  : they determine the structure of the economy , establish incentives for economic behavior , and affect social interaction [ 12 ] .	North
Thus , [MASK] also determine the level of uncertainty to which individuals are subject , stimulating or discouraging transactions .	institutions
A viable [MASK] requires an institutional structure that reduces existing uncertainty and guarantees property rights .	economy
Of course , the [MASK] takes a lead role in promoting this type of institution .	state
The [MASK] must protect property rights , provide public services , and ensure a sound judiciary .	state
[MASK] is responsible also for imposing order and promoting a climate of cooperation among agents , penalizing all violators of contracts [ 17 ] .	It
The [MASK] to a prosperous society is not an easy one .	path
If there are disagreements about the policies to be implemented , then the [MASK] that wins the political game will make the final decision .	group
On the one hand , a [MASK] that adopts policies promoting inclusive political institutions will develop pluralist and centralized institutions .	society
Inclusive [MASK] guarantee the right to private property , to an impartial legal system and promote a society based on equal conditions .	institutions
These [MASK] benefit not only the elites , but society as a whole .	institutions
In governments with extractive policies , the [MASK] in power usually extracts resources from the rest of the population for its own enrichment and well - being .	group
Another feature of this type of government is that powerful interest [MASK] oppose increased pluralism because it typically results in the loss of their privileges .	groups
[MASK] in power have little interest in their power devolving to a greater number of agents , as would occur under political institutions that were more pluralistic [ 16 ] .	Those
The institutional [MASK] of a state and its constitution are responsible for restricting predatory action  even by the state itself  and for creating rules that benefit the community [ 18 ] .	structure
Moreover , compliance [MASK] must reflect ex ante and ex post standards [ 12 ] .	mechanisms
But [MASK] happens when property rights are not respected ?	what
All these [MASK] have a place in this case analysis .	questions
The [MASK] of YPF is a case in which the Argentine State presents predatory behavior , encouraged by an extractive institutional framework .	expropriation
In a scenario with insecure property rights , asymmetric information , and a judicial system that acts as a lax enforcement mechanism , as discussed in the following sections , the [MASK] is difficult to attract .	FDI
In order to understand policymaking and its effects , [MASK] must have adequate knowledge of the focal country s institutional framework .	one
[MASK] of Argentina s governments have been of the predatory type .	Most
The country s unequal economic [MASK] originated in the colonial era and reflects how the Spanish metropolis influenced the establishment of extractive institutions [ 7 ] .	growth
Argentine [MASK] are therefore highly unstable .	politics
[MASK] takes place when a syntactic unit is broken up across two lines of poetry ( Domnguez Caparrs , 2000 : 103 ) , giving rise to different stylistic effects ( e.g. increased emphasis on elements of the broken - up phrase , or contrast between those elements ) , or creating double interpretations for the enjambed lines ( Garca - Paje , 1991 ) .	Enjambment
However , a larger - scale [MASK] to identify enjambment across hundreds of authors spanning several centuries , enabling distant reading ( Moretti , 2013 ) , was not previously available .	study
Given that need , [MASK] have developed software , based on Natural Language Processing , that automatically identifies enjambment in Spanish , and applied it to a corpus of approx. 3750 sonnets by ca. 1000 authors , from the 15th to the 19th century .	we
[MASK] is the interest of such large - scale automatic analyses of enjambment ?	What
First , the [MASK] shows a debate about which specific syntactic units can be considered to trigger enjambment , if split across two lines , and whether lexical and syntactic criteria are sufficient to identify enjambment .	literature
Second , the stylistic [MASK] that enjambment permits are also an object of current research ( Martnez Fernndez , 2010 ) .	effects
Finally , our [MASK] complements Navarro s ( 2016 ) automatic metrical analyses of Spanish Golden Age sonnets , by covering a wider period and focusing on enjambment .	study
First [MASK] provide the definition of enjambment adopted .	we
The project s [MASK] provides details omitted here for space reasons , including samples for the corpus , results , and other details .	website
Syntactic and metrical [MASK] often match in poetry .	units
[MASK] ( 1964 ) performed poetry reading experiments , proposing that the following strongly connected elements give rise to enjambment , should a poetic - form pause break them up :	Quilis
[MASK] translated " lexical enjambment " from Quilis s terms " encabalgamiento lxico " or " tmesis " .	We
[MASK] translated " phrase - bounded enjambment " from " encabalgamiento sirremtico " .	We
[MASK] translated " cross-clause enjambment " from Quilis s " encabalgamiento oracional " .	We
The project [MASK] includes Quilis s complete list of syntactic environments that can trigger enjambment , as well as the types identified by our system .	site
Besides the enjambment types above , [MASK] ( 1983 ) noted that if a subject or direct object and their related verbs occur in two different lines of poetry , this can also feel unusual for a reader , even if the effect is less pronounced than in the environments identified by Quilis .	Spang
To differentiate these cases from enjambment proper , [MASK] calls these cases " enlace " , translated here as " expansion " .	Spang
[MASK] ( 1964 ) was the only author so far to gather recitation - based experimental evidence on enjambment .	Quilis
Our [MASK] identifies Quilis  types , besides Spang s expansion cases .	system
[MASK] can rationally choose between experts only if the criteria that distinguish genuine experts from charlatans are common sense or widely known :	Agents
if agents are to satisfy the epistemic conditions on responsibility , [MASK] must know what kinds of knowledge they must utilize to guide their selection of sources ( on pain of infinite regress ) .	they
In fact , many , if not all , the [MASK] of expertise identified by philosophers enjoy widespread recognition .	markers
The [MASK] that these criteria are widely known , however , offers an opportunity to those who would use them for deception , witting or unwitting .	fact
[MASK] live in an epistemic environment that is heavily and deliberately polluted by agents who use mimicry and other methods as a means of inflating their pretense to expertise .	We
This [MASK] , together with the fact that such deception is widely known to occur , reduces ordinary people s trust in expert authority and diminishes their capacity to distinguish reliable from unreliable sources .	fact
For instance , [MASK] with an interest in deceiving the general public may set up parallel institutions that ostensibly guarantee expertise , taking advantage of the ways in which these parallel institutions mimic legitimate institutions to ensure that people are taken in .	those
For example , a small [MASK] of doctors set up the American College of Pediatricians ( ACPeds ) to advocate socially conservative viewpoints related to child health care .	number
Such an [MASK] is surely permissible , but it has had the unfortunate ( and likely intended ) effect of muddying debates in the public forum by misleading people into thinking that the college speaks for the pediatric profession at large .	organization
Thus , when ACPeds issued a statement condemning gender reassignment surgery in 2016 [ 21 ] , many [MASK] mistook the organization s political beliefs for the consensus view among United States pediatricians  although the peak body for pediatric workers , the American Academy of Pediatrics , has a much more positive view of gender dysphoria [ 22 ] .	people
When ACPeds allows or encourages the impression that it speaks for the profession , [MASK] introduces an epistemic pollutant .	it
A yet more egregious [MASK] of such pollution involved collaborative efforts by pharmaceutical companies and the publishing giant Elsevier to produce publications mimicking peer - reviewed journals in the interest of promoting the companies  commercial products [ 23 ] .	example
The [MASK] hoped to leverage the prestige of Elsevier with these fake journals to endow their promotional  research  with an air of reliability .	companies
When the deceit was uncovered , however , the [MASK] was just the opposite :	effect
More recently , [MASK] of academic expertise have been subject to a large and growing outbreak of so - called predatory journals  journals that will publish almost anything for a fee .	institutions
Once again , this [MASK] has the effect of making peer - reviewed journals appear less legitimate .	phenomenon
At times , even [MASK] who work in academia may be unsure of a particular journal s legitimacy , and there are genuine borderline cases .	those
For example , the Frontiers [MASK] of journals appears legitimate  at least to me  despite the fact that authors are expected to pay a publication fee . 8	contingent
Yet some Frontiers [MASK] appear to have engaged in bad behavior , whether for profit or for some other motive .	journals
[MASK] in Public Health controversially published articles linking vaccines and autism [ 24 ] and questioning the link between HIV and AIDS [ 25 ] .	Frontiers
Whether due to this behavior or not , [MASK] Beall decided to add the publisher to his influential ( but now sadly unavailable ) list of questionable journals [ 26 ] .	Jeffrey
The [MASK] surrounding Beall s decision indicates how difficult it is to make such judgments  even for professionals .	controversy
If academics with expertise in relevant fields have difficulty assessing whether particular journals or particular publishers are legitimate , [MASK] can not reasonably expect ordinary people to make such judgments .	one
If their confidence in scientific findings is lowered across the board as the result of such epistemic pollution , [MASK] can hardly blame them .	one
Epistemic [MASK] may stem not only from counterfeit institutions of knowledge production but also from bad behavior by legitimate institutions . 9	pollution
For example , [MASK] may result from attempts to game the systems put in place to track expertise .	pollution
These [MASK] do not exist solely to credential experts .	institutions
[MASK] have other functions , and these functions may come into conflict , creating pressures to inflate credentials .	They
For example , [MASK] have a financial incentive to inflate the expertise of their academic staff , thereby increasing their rankings , bringing in grant money , and attracting students .	universities
For this reason , [MASK] may also be slow to investigate accusations of fraud , and they may try to keep their discoveries in - house to protect their reputations .	institutions
Cognitive [MASK] involve a number of different games working aspects of human cognition , while proposing the intersection between the sets of concepts , fun and cognition , for the improvement of cognitive functions .	games
The [MASK] is the main point made in this study , since it is fundamental to the learning process and be recurring complaint among parents and teachers in schools .	attention
With respect to the contributions of digital games to improvement of cognitive processes , [MASK] suggest that regular practice has a significant influence on improving the performance related to basic visual skills ( Li , Polat , Scalzo , & Bavelier , 2010 ) ; on the ability to perceive objects simultaneously ( Dye & Bavelier , 2010 ; Feng , Spence , & Pratt , 2007 ) ; and on the ability to do more than one task at the same time ( Boot , Kramer , Simons , Fabiani , & Gratton , 2008 ) .	researchers
Other [MASK] specifically investigate the use of digital games in the school context and suggest potential for digital game use to improve of student 's attention span at preschool age ( Rueda , Checa , & Cmbita , 2012 ) , to improve overall intelligence capacity of elementary school children ( Miller & Robertson , 2010 ) , and to better performance of working memory ability ( Klingberg et al. , 2005 ; Thorell , Lindqvist , Nutley , Bohlin , & Klingberg , 2009 ) .	studies
The [MASK] in question focuses on the attention , proposing and evaluation in the context of the classroom .	study
Thus , [MASK] suggests the use of digital games in an integrated way the school activities in the classroom .	it
The [MASK] have features like increasing challenges , rules that establish what can and can not be done , and involvement of the player in the quest to gain skills and win the game ( Kirriemuir & McFarlane , 2004 ; Prensky , 2005 ) .	games
[MASK] aim to investigate the contributions of the use of a system that integrates cognitive digital games to a database , of the Escola do Crebro , for monitoring and improvement of cognitive skills , highlighting the attention .	We
The [MASK] involve challenges and rules involving the exercise of cognitive functions , especially the working memory , attention and capacity of solving problems .	games
The [MASK] combines qualitative and quantitative approaches .	study
[MASK] collects the data based on the observation of the proposed interventions as well as interviews conducted with participating teachers and students to identify their perceptions of digital games  contributions to the learning process .	It
Furthermore , before and after the implementation of the intervention , [MASK] performed a D2 Test of attention that measures selective and sustained attention , as well as visual scanning accuracy and speed .	we
The [MASK] consisted in the use of the Escola do Crebro , using tablets in the classroom , daily for a period of five weeks .	intervention
The [MASK] consisted of 71 students of the Application School of Basic Education , Federal University of Santa Catarina , aged 7 and 9 years old ( M = 7.64  1.12 ) , which were divided into two groups : participant and control .	sample
The [MASK] ( n = 31 ) participated in the intervention , the control group ( n = 40 ) was only evaluated using the test before and after the same time interval of interventions .	first
The [MASK] do Crebro is a platform that integrates seven digital games into a database .	Escola
The [MASK] allows visualization of the player 's performance and offers the possibility of monitoring by teachers .	application
[MASK] have their scores measured by four variables : time , speed , stability and accuracy .	Students
The [MASK] in the results obtained from the application of D2 Test of attention before and after was statistically significant ( p < 0.05 ) , the participant group had mean and standard deviation 60.23 ( 64.75 ) respectively , while the control group was 20.00 ( 42.65 ) .	difference
The [MASK] indicates significant improvement in the performance of the sustained attention in the test , as well as a high dispersion , which reveals a variation in relation to the performance .	result
In addition , [MASK] participating in the interview reported a preference for games that involve problem solving , recognize the need to plan actions in relation to their importance for the game and for daily activities , and realize improvements in the ability to sustain attention .	students
The [MASK] observed changes after the intervention , emphasizing the greater persistence and involvement in school activities , and in some students , improvement in the ability to sustain attention .	teachers
From this , [MASK] conclude that an intervention based on cognitive digital games offers contributions to the learning process and improvement of sustained attention .	we
A fundamental tenet of linguistic science is that the [MASK] of a word has a purely arbitrary connection to the word 's meaning [ 1 ] , [ 2 ] .	sound
But it is not that a [MASK] can have just any vocal sound .	word
While the possibility space for sound systems of the world 's language is enormous , any given [MASK] makes use of only a restricted portion of the possible sounds [ 3 ] , [ 4 ] .	language
But in this study [MASK] present a striking exception to this otherwise robust rule .	we
From a systematic comparison of 10 spoken languages from 5 continents [MASK] find evidence suggesting that a word like  Huh ?   used as a  repair initiator  when , for example , one has not clearly heard what someone just said [ 5 ] , [ 6 ]  is a universal word .	we
In support of the first claim , [MASK] show that the similarities in form and function of an interjection with the specific function of repair initiation are very much greater across languages than chance coincidence would admit .	we
In fact the [MASK] in form in unrelated languages across the globe is about the same as the variation we find in the way any regular word ( e.g. , dog ) is pronounced across dialects of English .	variation
In support of the second claim , [MASK] show that Huh ? meets the criteria of a word in the sense of being a conventional lexical sign which must be learnt .	we
Thus , in contrast to what has been presumed for interjections in general [ 7 ] , [ 8 ] and for huh ? in particular [ 9 ] , [ 10 ] , [MASK] find that this item is linguistic in nature rather than being a mere grunt or non-lexical sound .	we
[MASK] show that the form is locally calibrated in ways that show it fitting within different language systems .	We
[MASK] ? may be a non-prototypical word , but it is a word .	Huh
Finally , [MASK] address the question of why all languages should have such a word and why its form should be so similar across languages .	we
[MASK] observe that this item fulfils a crucial need shared by all languages  the efficient signalling of problems of hearing and understanding  and we propose that its form is constrained by selective pressures in a conversational environment that is essentially the same in all languages .	We
After speaker G makes a statement , [MASK] E utters the interjection huh ? .	speaker
The technical [MASK] for this type of sequence is  open other - initiated repair  :	term
The actual repair [MASK] in response to this interjection is usually simply repetition , sometimes with slight modification .	operation
[MASK] 2 and 3 show structurally identical sequences in two other languages : Siwu , a Kwa language spoken in Ghana , and Lao , a Tai - Kadai language spoken in Laos .	Extracts
These [MASK] show that it is possible to identify the same conversational structure in unrelated languages .	examples
Essentially , this [MASK] gives us a natural control over conversational data , making possible systematic comparison across languages [ 12 ] , [ 13 ] .	method
[MASK] leads to the question driving our study :	This
is [MASK] ? in this context a universal word ?	huh
By compiling data from published literature [MASK] found that in thirty - one languages around the world , the interjection for other - initiated repair appears to be strongly similar ( Figure 1 ) .	we
However , written [MASK] are rarely explicit about the precise form , meaning , and use of interjections .	sources
Therefore [MASK] collected data from recordings of naturally occurring informal conversations in a sample of 10 languages from 5 continents , varying fundamentally in terms of phonology , word structure , and grammar ( languages 1  10 in Figure 1 ) .	we
For optimal comparability , [MASK] studied the exact same conversational environment across languages : that of other - initiated repair ( OIR ) , in which one participant produces a turn at talk , the other then signals some trouble with this turn , and finally the first produces a next turn which aims to solve the trouble , usually by means of repetition and / or modification .	we
Such alternative ( and probably derived ) [MASK] provide insight in possible paths of semantic change , but we exclude them here to make sure we are comparing like with like .	uses
[MASK] hypothesized that the children , who were over the age of six at the time of collection , would have adult - like SI interpretations .	We
[MASK] expected that the use of a training session and then the format of the question would guide participants towards evaluating pragmatic felicity over providing truth value judgments , and would result in adult - like interpretations .	We
Further , [MASK] posited that if our initial hypothesis was not supported , and in fact there was some non - adult - like performance , that there would be significant variability among the conditions , with cardinal numbers having the highest performance and some the weakest .	we
[MASK] serves as a reminder of the work that needs to be completed for the cross-linguistic study of SI in particular and acquisition more generally .	It
Future [MASK] need to include more participants and more items to increase power .	studies
Future [MASK] should also include a larger age range of children to document the age at which adult - like performance emerges .	studies
Related cross-cultural [MASK] have resulted in insufficient statistical power , but interesting trends ( e.g. , Nedwick , 2014 ) .	studies
Previous [MASK] in this region of sub-Saharan Africa have found evidence of cultural differences in testing behavior ( Hein , Reich , Marks , Thuma , & Grigorenko , 2016 ) .	studies
The current [MASK] is too small to make strong conclusions with regard to cultural differences and experimental methods ;	study
More specifically , [MASK] answered  yes  that the puppet described the pictures well .	they
[MASK] is unlikely as they said that even the first training item was said well .	This
Additional [MASK] with the methodology could improve outcomes .	training
Further [MASK] with greater cardinal number ranges could also prove interesting .	exploration
The cardinal [MASK] included in this study were only one through five in order to avoid additional item variability , but larger numbers should be included in future research .	numbers
Albeit limited , these [MASK] provide valuable insight into SI interpretation by Chitonga - speaking children and demonstrate that pragmatic inference acquisition likely follows the order identified in previous research , but appears to be completed at a later age in this language .	results
This interesting [MASK] of findings  expected hierarchy of difficulty , but differing age of acquisition  is an important addition to our growing cross-linguistic knowledge of SI and could be the result of language - specific differences in the use of SI lexical items or methodological differences .	combination
Today s [MASK] will not survive a day without the help of lighting .	generation
In fact , someone s [MASK] , particularly at night , depends on the presence of a good lighting and it seems that it is a daily necessity .	productivity
[MASK] takes a large part on the consumption of household electrical energy particularly in the Philippines .	Lighting
Nowadays , most commonly and widely used [MASK] in the household is the Compact Fluorescent Light ( CFL ) .	bulb
However , the main [MASK] of CFL is the mercury they contain .	problem
In response to the said problem , this project [MASK] gives solution to the problem of the society concerning environment , health and safety as well energy conservation , by developing a segmented compact light - emitting diode ( SCLED ) bulb from busted CFL that are efficient , economical , and does not contain toxic chemicals .	study
Based on the results of the 2011 Household Energy Consumption Survey ( HECS ) , [MASK] remains as the most common source of energy used by households particularly in the Philippines .	electricity
About 87 [MASK] of 21.0 million households used electricity from March to August 2011 .	percent
As of 2016 , the [MASK] for electricity in the residential is leading among the different sectors .	demand
Now that the world is in the age where lighting seems to be a daily necessity , typical [MASK] as shown in figure 1 , consume nearly 27 percent of the energy used today : making lighting as the major source of electricity consumption .	homes
[MASK] plays a large part on the consumption of household electrical energy ; it consumes about 18 % of the total generated electricity of total energy consumption in residential sectors as shown in figure 2 [ 2 ] .	Lighting
[MASK] of the main factors in lighting energy consumption is the light bulb .	One
The [MASK] of correct and appropriate type of light bulb improves the efficiency of energy usage .	use
But [MASK] of them has their perks and perils [ 3 ] .	each
Unfortunately , most of the time , [MASK] in the residential end up choosing a lamp based on it is price rather than its efficiency and this cause us to pay for our lighting more than necessary .	people
Today , [MASK] are the most used lighting sources in the household .	CFLs
However , the main [MASK] of CFLs is the mercury they contain .	problem
[MASK] is persistent in the environment ; it never breaks down nor goes away .	It
This UV [MASK] interacts with the chemicals on the inside of the bulb to generate light .	radiation
The acute and chronic [MASK] are the normal responses of the skin to UVR ; acute reactions considered will be erythema ( sunburn ) and vitamin D production .	effects
In response to the aforementioned situation where the three types of lights are compared by their efficiency and effectiveness as light sources , the [MASK] conducted this study .	proponents
Since the CFLs are the most commonly used light bulbs in the residential and has a great compatibility to LED in terms of design and materials , the [MASK] conducted a study about innovating and recycling CFL into a more efficient and environment friendly LED light bulb .	proponents
In this article , [MASK] propose the definition of specific mutation operators for testing Geographic Information Systems .	we
[MASK] describe the process for applying the operators and generating mutants , and present a case study where these mutation operators are applied to two real - world applications .	We
[MASK] : mutation operators ; geographic information systems ; mutation testing	Keywords
Mutation - based [MASK] [ 1 ] is a test technique that involves artificially introducing errors into a System Under Test ( SUT ) .	testing
A [MASK] is a copy of the system in which a change has been done that , in most cases , will lead to a behaviour different than expected .	mutant
In the state of the art , [MASK] have found mutation operators , both general purpose and specific to different technologies , languages and paradigms [ 2  9 ] .	we
However , these [MASK] are not adequate when trying to test software features associated with specific domains .	operators
In this article , [MASK] propose mutation operators specific to the domain of Geographic Information Systems ( GIS ) applications .	we
These [MASK] reproduce programming errors that are litely to occur during the development of this type of applications .	operators
In addition , [MASK] present the implementation of these operators and as proof of concept we apply these operators to two real - world GIS applications and we generate the mutants .	we
As a previous step to designing the mutation operators , [MASK] analyzed the main technologies used specifically in the development of GIS , and we identified typical errors a programmer can introduce during the development .	we
In order to apply these operators to a SUT , [MASK] rely on Java reflection and aspect - oriented programming .	we
[MASK] allows us to obtain the list of classes and methods of the SUT , so the user can decide the methods to wish the operators will be applied .	Reflection
Later , [MASK] capture information about the methods of the SUT to be mutated , together with the information of the mutation operators that were already defined .	we
From these data , [MASK] generate the mutation operator , in the form of on aspect , which will then be possible to interweave with the SUT which generates a mutant of the SUT .	we
Next , [MASK] describe the definition of two operators and two cases of application on real - world GIS applications .	we
[MASK] exchanges the coordinate system of a geometry , so it does not match the coordinate system that is being used in the user interface .	It
[MASK] simulates the error of not checking that the coordinate system is correct .	It
This [MASK] allows registering places of interest for the user .	application
By creating a Geofence with an erroneous location from its central location , the [MASK] will receive incorrect location notifications .	device
As a result , the [MASK] will see in the application s map viewer the Geofences drawn in erroneous zones ( Figure 1 ) .	user
[MASK] introduces errors in the processing of geometries , manipulating the result of the operations that carry out the verification of different topological restrictions between geometries , such as intersects , covers or overlap .	It
This [MASK] causes the incorrect display of the resulting geometry that should be drawn in the user interface after the operation applied to the two initial geometries ( Figure 2 ) .	error
In existing proposals , [MASK] can find both generic and specific mutation operators .	we
However , [MASK] are not adequate to cover errors in particular domains .	these
[MASK] have defined new operators specific to the GIS domain and a way to apply them to a SUT .	We
In addition , [MASK] have tested the operators defined in two GIS applications .	we
As future work , [MASK] intend to extend this approach to other domains , as well as to use the developed operators for the automatic improvement of sets of test cases .	we
When using the same materials and procedures as a previous study , replication [MASK] serve to test the reliability of the previous study s findings .	studies
When altering specific methodological or participant characteristics of a previous study , [MASK] serve to test generalizability of the earlier findings under different conditions .	they
Beyond these calls , [MASK] to actively promote and facilitate replication studies have also emerged .	efforts
The Open Science [MASK] ( https://osf.io ) , also established in 2011 , provides a web infrastructure to facilitate collaboration and has been used for large replication efforts in psychology ( e.g. , Open Science Collaboration , 2015 ) , which continue to make waves in academia ( Laws , 2016 ; Lindsay , 2015 ; Martin & Clarke , 2017 ) and the general media ( Baker , 2015 ; Devlin , 2016 ) .	Framework
In some fields , a flourishing [MASK] , that is , the scientific study of science ( see Munaf et al. , 2017 ) , has included syntheses assessing the quantity and nature of replication efforts , for example , in education ( Makel & Plucker , 2014 and in psychology ( Makel et al. , 2012 ) .	metascience
The driving [MASK] behind this battery of calls , commentaries , infrastructure , and metascience is a perceived crisis in the state of replication research .	force
The severe [MASK] underpinning the alleged crisis have several dimensions relating to : (a) the ( small ) amount of published replication research ; (b) the ( poor ) quality of replication research ; and (c) the ( lack of ) reproducibility , which refers to the extent to which findings can ( not ) be reproduced in replication attempts that have been undertaken .	concerns
These [MASK] speak to the very core of science , raising fundamental questions about the validity and reliability of our work .	concerns
Indeed , some [MASK] have called replication the  gold standard  of research evidence ( Jasny , Chin , Chong , & Vignieri , 2011 , p. 1225 ) and a  linchpin of the scientific process  ( Let s replicate , 2006 , p. 330 ) .	commentators
In the field of L2 research , given the importance of replication and the 50 calls for replication in L2 research that we identified , [MASK] might expect a substantial number of published replication studies by now .	one
However , a perceived [MASK] of prestige , excitement , and originality of replication plagues L2 research ( Porte , 2012 ) , as it does other disciplines ( Berez - Kroeker et al. , 2017 ; Branco , Cohen , Vossen , Ide , & Calzolari , 2017 ; Chambers , 2017 ; Schmidt , 2009 ) , and these perceptions are thought to have caused , at least in part ( directly or indirectly ) , alleged low rates and a poor quality of published replication studies .	lack
The current [MASK] begins to address this gap through narrative and systematic reviews .	study
The narrative [MASK] considers challenges in replication research and is largely informed by commentaries and metascience from psychology , given that the cognitive and social subdomains of psychology are highly influential in L2 research , and also from education , another key sister discipline .	review
To gain insight into these issues in the context of L2 research , the systematic [MASK] provides a synthesis of L2 studies in journal articles that self - labeled as replications .	review
Finally , [MASK] offer further discussion and 16 recommendations for future replication work that draw on our narrative and systematic reviews and on our experience of carrying out multisite ( Morgan - Short et al. , 2018 ) 1 and single site ( Faretta - Stutenberg & Morgan - Short , 2011 ; Marsden , Williams , & Liu , 2013 ; McManus & Marsden , 2017 ; Morgan - Short , Heil , Botero - Moriaty , & Ebert , 2012 ) replications .	we
[MASK] start from the widely agreed premise that testing the reproducibility of findings should have an essential role in the testing and refinement of theory , at least for hypothesis - testing epistemologies that seek to ascertain generalizability and for other epistemologies in which constructs are deemed to be definable and observable .	We
[MASK] is one of the most important marine parameters , which controls many processes such as physical circulations , biogeochemistry dynamics from regional to global ocean [ 1 , 2 ] .	Salinity
In the past decade , with the successful launch of the soil moisture and ocean salinity ( SMOS ) satellite by the European Space Agency ( ESA ) [ 3 ] , the Aquarius / SAC-D satellite [ 4 ] , and the soil moisture active passive ( SMAP ) satellite [ 5 , 6 ] by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration ( NASA ) , global sea surface salinity ( SSS ) [MASK] from space have become possible and a significant improvement has been made to understand the ocean dynamics and climate change .	observations
At the end of 1990 , two airborne microwave [MASK] , the electronically scanned thinned array radiometer ( ESTAR ) and the scanning low - frequency microwave radiometer ( SLFMR ) , successfully produced SSS maps in coastal areas in agreement with in - situ measurements with an accuracy of about 1 psu .	interferometers
However , the [MASK] of satellite measured brightness temperature to SSS is quite low .	sensitivity
For example , the [MASK] of vertically polarized brightness temperature to SSS variation is 0.4 to 0.8 K/psu for different observing angles and sea surface temperatures ( SST ) , and it is only 0.2 to 0.6 K/psu for the horizontal polarization brightness temperature [ 10 ] .	sensitivity
Thus , remote [MASK] of SSS requires a highly accurate retrieval model .	sensing
Besides the atmospheric effects , the [MASK] of sea surface emissivity due to the sea surface roughness and foam effects is the main source of error , which could significantly hamper the accuracy of SSS retrieval [ 11 ] .	increasing
Although many theoretical and empirical models have been developed , some [MASK] are still unsolved .	problems
For example , the [MASK] originally proposed to estimate brightness temperature at higher frequencies , uses the sea surface wave spectrum by multiplying a factor of 2 .	TSM
Moreover , the sea surface [MASK] of downwelling atmospheric emission is another contribution to satellite - observed brightness temperature [ 31 ] , thus the determination of the cutoff wavenumber is required not only for sea surface emission but also for reflection .	reflection
In addition , the widely used empirical [MASK] decouple the wind effect from SSS and SST effects , which means that the surface emission is due to a perfectly flat sea surface and the wind - roughened sea surface .	models
Thus , the [MASK] of these models in coastal area of China needs to be assessed and tested in order to achieve higher accuracies of SSS from the space - borne observations .	compatibility
[MASK] have shown that the addition of an artificial tail during ontogeny can produce postural and locomotory changes in chickens , consistent with the posture and kinematics inferred for non-avian dinosaurs [ 5 ] , [ 6 ] , [ 11 ] .	We
The posterior [MASK] of the CoM produced a more vertically oriented femur during standing ( femur in experimental animals was 40 % more vertical than control subjects ) , and increased femoral retraction and decreased knee flexion during walking .	displacement
These [MASK] indicate a shift from the standard bird , knee - driven bipedal locomotion to a more hip - driven locomotion , typical of crocodilians ( the only other extant archosaur group ) , mammals , and hypothetically , bipedal non-avian dinosaurs .	results
In fact , the control - weight [MASK] showed a more horizontally oriented femur during walking with respect to the control group , similar to that observed in Carrano and Biewener 's experimental subjects [ 7 ] .	subjects
Therefore , [MASK] conclude that the location of the CoM can be a key factor in defining limb posture and kinematics .	we
Our [MASK] show that for a given CFL mass , femoral retraction can be greatly affected by the location of the CoM and limb postures .	data
[MASK] in limb orientation can produce substantial differences in loading regimes on limb bones .	Differences
The [MASK] of each limb element to the ground reaction force ( GRF ) indicates the relative contribution of axial and bending forces to external bone loading : a bone perpendicular to the GRF is expected experience greater bending forces than one parallel to the GRF .	orientation
[MASK] have relatively shorter , stouter femora than non-avian theropods , presumed to be associated with more horizontal orientation .	Birds
Experimental [MASK] of femoral orientation in chickens suggest that torsional loads increase as the femur becomes more horizontal [ 7 ] supporting the idea that postural differences could be reflected in differences in limb cross-sectional geometry .	manipulations
To test if the postural differences observed in this study produced changes in limb morphology , [MASK] measured the length and mid-shaft cross-sectional properties of the femur in all our individuals .	we
However , [MASK] found no differences in cross-sectional femoral geometry among groups .	we
Maybe [MASK] is not surprising considering that a recent study analyzing the relationship between posture and femur cross-sectional properties failed to find differences between birds and non-avian theropods [ 24 ] , suggesting that simple morphological correlates of limb posture should be used with caution .	this
Interestingly , femur [MASK] tended to be greater in the experimental group than in both the control - weight and the control group ( by 4 and 7 % , respectively ) , although not signifcant .	length
If this were the case , [MASK] would support the idea that non-avian theropods have relatively thinner femora than extant birds because of postural differences [ 6 ] .	it
[MASK] suggest that the different outcomes are due to the distinct rearing and exercising conditions used in each study , in addition to the different artificial tails used .	We
First , our experimental [MASK] lived in a large enclosure under conditions that allowed them to exercise all day long .	subjects
During avian evolution , the [MASK] of the CFL and reorganization of the pelvic musculature [ 5 ] , [ 13 ] could have made birds unable to properly carry a postacetabular mass equivalent to that carried by non-avian theropods [ 5 ] , [ 6 ] .	loss
In our experimental setup , [MASK] attempted to more closely mimic non-avian theropod tail morphology , in which mass is distributed through a distally tapering tail .	we
In addition , [MASK] reduced the total tail mass to 15 % body mass from the 20 % body mass used by Carrano and Biewener .	we
Thus , our [MASK] seems to have generated a more gradual and less pronounced change in the moment of inertia produced by the artificial tail , allowing experimental subjects to adjust to the posterior mass by adopting a more vertical position of the femur while standing .	study
Interestingly , the femur [MASK] during walking in our control - weight group resembles the results reported in the experimental subjects of Carrano and Biewener .	kinematics
[MASK] suggests that their results could be partially explained as a response to the increased loading rather than to the displacement of the CoM .	This
However , substantial [MASK] in hindlimb morphology between these groups make difficult to assess the validity of inferences obtained from such studies .	differences
One caveat , however , is that our [MASK] uses tail reduction as the mechanism for CoM displacement despite it has been recently shown that the evolutionary change in CoM position was driven instead by forelimb enlargement [ 8 ] .	approach
Nonetheless , [MASK] does not mean that tail reduction had no effect on CoM displacement , but that it was not the most important factor .	this
Ideally [MASK] would have increased tail mass and reduced pectoral limb mass but , unfortunately , this is not experimentally feasible .	we
[MASK] argue that our experimental approach , although not perfect , was effective in displacing the CoM and recreating locomotor patterns expected in non-avian theropods .	We
Thus , [MASK] expect that careful phenotypic manipulation of extant birds can open new avenues of experimental investigation into unexplored facets of dinosaur locomotor mechanics and energetics , providing a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between form and function in dinosaur evolution .	we
[MASK] is a transmedia system in the sense first used by Marsha Kinder ( 1991 ) and popularized by Henry Jenkins ( 2006 ) , in which media - hopping networks of intertextualities extend the  storyworld  of an original production .	it
Now spanning six seasons and 60 episodes , with an average global viewership ( from its most recent season ) of 25.1 million viewers per episode ( Shepherd , 2016 ) , [MASK] has spawned five video games , a graphic novel adaptation , several companion books , two rap albums , a 28 - city orchestral tour , a wide variety of tabletop games , toys , merchandise and mobile apps , and countless podcasts , fanfics and other fan - based creations .	it
As such , the Game of Thrones [MASK] represents a remarkably rich and challenging environment for fans old and new , who must negotiate an increasingly complex network of paratexts and intertexts in order to fully engage with its narratives .	storyworld
In this sense , [MASK] of the series represent an emerging model for cultural consumption that should be carefully explored .	fans
Transmedia [MASK] , like that exemplified by Game of Thrones , are becoming increasingly prevalent ( e.g. , Star Wars , Harry Potter , The Walking Dead , the Marvel Cinematic Universe , etc ) ; these systems demonstrate , in microcosm , the global challenge of managing the fire - hose flow of information in contemporary postdigital society .	systems
The [MASK] of how people , as fans , access and manage information within a transmedia system provides valuable insight that contributes not only to practitioners and scholars of the media industry , but to the wider context of cultural studies , by offering findings on this new model of the fan as consumer and information - user .	study
As a first step in defining the  transmedia fan  , the current [MASK] undertakes a comparative discourse analysis of online conversations of Game of Thrones fans .	project
[MASK] of the book series had long anticipated and dreaded the events of the  Red Wedding  , while fans of the show unfamiliar with Martin s narrative were largely taken unawares by the pivotal episode .	Readers
Since the television series  inception , [MASK] at The AV Club have written two critical reviews for each episode :	writers
[MASK] results are two completely separate reviews of  The Rains of Castamere  which in turn document the fans  reactions to the episode in the form of user comment threads :	What
As a pilot project , the current [MASK] takes the content of both comment threads  a corpus of approximately 5,600 comments  and analyzes each thread separately using a qualitative coding method aligned with constructivist grounded theory ( Charmaz , 2006 ) .	work
Through this analysis , a [MASK] of themes emerges illustrating tactics for negotiating intertexts and paratexts unique to each group of fans .	categorization
These [MASK] fall under two broad categories :	themes
A [MASK] of categories and sub-categories between both groups provides preliminary findings to support an emergent model , or models , of the  transmedia fan  .	comparison
The present [MASK] represents a first step in exploring the impact of transmedia systems , as exemplified by Game of Thrones , through the study of fans .	research
The [MASK] posed by this research is , fundamentally , an examination of how the problem of  access  is framed in postdigital society from the perspective of the consumer .	question
Future [MASK] should explore the negotiation tactics observed in transmedia fans using the principles of De Certeau s ( 1984 ) everyday life practice , in order to extend its application to the broader context of modern - day consumers .	research
The current [MASK] will contribute to the development of further qualitative and quantitative research that will more clearly define the information behaviors of the transmedia fan .	study
This [MASK] is of relevance to researchers in media studies , fan studies , information studies and digital humanities .	project
[MASK] Bernoulli FRS ( German pronunciation : [ bnli ] ; 8 February 1700  17 March 1782 ) was a Swiss mathematician and physicist and was one of the many prominent mathematicians in the Bernoulli family .	Daniel
The Bernoulli [MASK] came originally from Antwerp , at that time in the Spanish Netherlands , but emigrated to escape the Spanish persecution of the Huguenots .	family
After a brief period in Frankfurt the [MASK] moved to Basel , in Switzerland .	family
[MASK] was a son of Johann Bernoulli ( one of the " early developers " of calculus ) and a nephew of Jacob Bernoulli ( who " was the first to discover the theory of probability " ) .	Daniel
[MASK] had two brothers , Niklaus and Johann II .	He
Upon both of them entering and tying for first place in a scientific contest at the University of Paris , [MASK] , unable to bear the " shame " of being compared Daniel 's equal , banned Daniel from his house .	Johann
[MASK] Bernoulli also plagiarized some key ideas from Daniel 's book Hydrodynamica in his own book Hydraulica which he backdated to before Hydrodynamica .	Johann
Despite Daniel 's attempts at reconciliation , his [MASK] carried the grudge until his death .	father
Around schooling age , his [MASK] , Johann , encouraged him to study business , there being poor rewards awaiting a mathematician .	father
However , [MASK] refused , because he wanted to study mathematics .	Daniel
[MASK] later gave in to his father 's wish and studied business .	He
His [MASK] then asked him to study in medicine , and Daniel agreed under the condition that his father would teach him mathematics privately , which they continued for some time .	father
[MASK] studied medicine at Basel , Heidelberg , and Strasbourg , and earned a PhD in anatomy and botany in 1721 .	Daniel
[MASK] was a contemporary and close friend of Leonhard Euler .	He
[MASK] went to St. Petersburg in 1724 as professor of mathematics , but was very unhappy there , and a temporary illness in 1733 gave him an excuse for leaving St. Petersburg .	He
[MASK] returned to the University of Basel , where he successively held the chairs of medicine , metaphysics , and natural philosophy until his death .	He
His earliest mathematical [MASK] was the Exercitationes ( Mathematical Exercises ) , published in 1724 with the help of Goldbach .	work
Two years later [MASK] pointed out for the first time the frequent desirability of resolving a compound motion into motions of translation and motion of rotation .	he
His chief [MASK] is Hydrodynamica , published in 1738 ;	work
[MASK] resembles Joseph Louis Lagrange 's Mcanique Analytique in being arranged so that all the results are consequences of a single principle , namely , conservation of energy .	it
[MASK] also wrote a large number of papers on various mechanical questions , especially on problems connected with vibrating strings , and the solutions given by Brook Taylor and by Jean le Rond d'Alembert .	Bernoulli
Together [MASK] and Euler tried to discover more about the flow of fluids .	Bernoulli
In particular , [MASK] wanted to know about the relationship between the speed at which blood flows and its pressure .	they
To investigate this , [MASK] experimented by puncturing the wall of a pipe with a small open ended straw and noted that the height to which the fluid rose up the straw was related to fluid 's pressure in the pipe .	Daniel
Soon [MASK] all over Europe were measuring patients ' blood pressure by sticking point - ended glass tubes directly into their arteries .	physicians
Taking his discoveries further , [MASK] Bernoulli now returned to his earlier work on Conservation of Energy .	Daniel
[MASK] realised that in a similar way , a moving fluid exchanges its kinetic energy for pressure .	Daniel
A consequence of this law is that if the velocity increases then the [MASK] falls .	pressure
The [MASK] in this area is lower than that under the wing , so the wing is pushed upwards by the relatively higher pressure under the wing .	pressure
Born in Tianjin with ancestry in Changzhou , Jiangsu province , [MASK] went to the United States with a Boxer Indemnity Scholarship in 1910 to study mathematics and physics at Cornell University , where he was a classmate and lifelong friend of Hu Shih , the leader of the New Culture Movement .	Chao
[MASK] then became interested in philosophy , and earned a Ph.D. in philosophy from Harvard University in 1918 with a dissertation entitled " Continuity : Study in Methodology " .	He
Already in college his [MASK] had turned to music and languages .	interests
[MASK] spoke German and French fluently and some Japanese , and he had a reading knowledge of ancient Greek and Latin .	He
[MASK] served as Bertrand Russell 's interpreter when Russell visited China in 1920 .	He
In his My Linguistic Autobiography , [MASK] wrote of his ability to pick up a Chinese dialect quickly , without much effort .	he
[MASK] possessed a natural gift for hearing fine distinctions in pronunciation that was said to be " legendary for its acuity " , enabling him to record the sounds of various dialects with a high degree of accuracy .	Chao
[MASK] returned to China in 1920 , marrying the physician Yang Buwei there that year .	He
The [MASK] was simple , rather than the noisy traditional wedding , attended only by Hu Shih and one other friend .	ceremony
Hu 's [MASK] of it in the newspapers made the couple a model of modern marriage for China 's New Culture generation .	account
[MASK] taught mathematics at Tsinghua University and , one year later , returned to the United States to teach at Harvard .	Chao
[MASK] again returned to China in 1925 , teaching at Tsinghua , and beginning a survey of the Wu dialects in 1926 .	He
[MASK] began to conduct linguistic fieldwork throughout China for the Institute of History and Philology of Academia Sinica from 1928 onwards .	He
During this period of time , [MASK] collaborated with Luo Changpei and Li Fang - Kuei , the other two leading Chinese linguists of his generation , to edit and render into Chinese Bernhard Karlgren 's monumental Etudes sur la Phonologie Chinoise ( published in 1940 ) .	he
[MASK] left for the US in 1938 , and resided there afterwards .	He
In 1945 , [MASK] served as president of the Linguistic Society of America , and a special issue of the society 's journal Language was dedicated to him in 1966 .	he
[MASK] became an American citizen in 1954 .	He
In the 1950s [MASK] was among the first members of the Society for General Systems Research .	he
From 1947 to 1960 , [MASK] taught at the University of California at Berkeley , where in 1952 , he became Agassiz Professor of Oriental Languages .	he
Previously at the invitation of Premier Zhou En - Lai , [MASK] and his wife returned to China in 1973 for the first time since the 1940s .	Chao
[MASK] visited China again between May and June in 1981 after his wife died in March the same year .	He
[MASK] died in Cambridge , Massachusetts .	He
His first [MASK] Rulan Chao Pian ( 1922 - 2013 ) was Professor of East Asian Studies and Music at Harvard .	daughter
His third [MASK] Lensey , born in 1929 , is a children 's book author and mathematician .	daughter
[MASK] Charles L'Enfant ( French : [ pj l lf ] ; August 2 , 1754  June 14 , 1825 ) , self - identified as Peter Charles L'Enfant while living in the United States , was a French - born American military engineer who designed the basic plan for Washington , D.C. ( capital city of the U.S. ) known today as the L'Enfant Plan ( 1791 ) .	Pierre
In 1758 , his [MASK] Pierre Joseph died at the age of six , and Pierre Charles became the eldest son .	brother
[MASK] studied art at the Royal Academy in the Louvre , as well as with his father at the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture .	He
[MASK] left school in France to enlist in the American Revolutionary War on the side of the rebelling colonials .	He
[MASK] arrived in 1777 at the age of 23 , and served as a military engineer in the Continental Army with Major General Lafayette .	He
Despite his aristocratic origins , [MASK] closely identified with the United States , changing his first name from Pierre to Peter when he first came to the rebelling colonies in 1777 .	L'Enfant
[MASK] served on General George Washington 's staff at Valley Forge .	L'Enfant
While there , the [MASK] de Lafayette commissioned L'Enfant to paint a portrait of Washington .	Marquis
[MASK] recovered and became a prisoner of war at surrender of Charleston , South Carolina on May 12 , 1780 .	He
After the war , [MASK] designed the badge of the Society of the Cincinnati , an organization of former officers of the Continental Army , shaped as an eagle , at the request of Washington .	L'Enfant
Following the American Revolutionary War , [MASK] established a successful and highly profitable civil engineering firm in New York City .	L'Enfant
[MASK] achieved some fame as an architect by redesigning the City Hall in New York for the First Congress of the United States ( See : Federal Hall ) .	He
[MASK] also designed furniture and houses for the wealthy as well as coins and medals , including the insignia of the Society of the Cincinnati .	He
[MASK] was also a friend of Alexander Hamilton , and some of their correspondances from 1790 to 1801 now reside in the National Archives .	He
His [MASK] took place on April 17 , 1789 , at Holland Lodge No. 8 , F&AM , which the Grand Lodge of New York F&AM had chartered in 1787 .	initiation
[MASK] took only the first of three degrees offered by the Lodge and did not progress further in Freemasonry .	L'Enfant
[MASK] J. Fillmore ( August 9 , 1929  February 13 , 2014 ) was an American linguist and Professor of Linguistics at the University of California , Berkeley .	Charles
[MASK] received his Ph.D. in Linguistics from the University of Michigan in 1961 .	He
[MASK] spent ten years at The Ohio State University and a year as a Fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University before joining Berkeley 's Department of Linguistics in 1971 . [ 1 ]	Fillmore
[MASK] was extremely influential in the areas of syntax and lexical semantics .	Fillmore
[MASK] received the 2012 Lifetime Achievement Award of the Association for Computational Linguistics . [ 3 ]	Fillmore
[MASK] died in 2014 . [ 4 ]	He
[MASK] spent three years in the U.S. Army stationed in Japan , where he intercepted coded Russian conversations on short - wave radio and taught himself Japanese . [ 2 ]	Fillmore
Following his discharge , [MASK] taught English at a Buddhist girls ' school while also taking classes at Kyoto University .	he
[MASK] returned to the US , receiving his doctorate at the University of Michigan and then teaching at The Ohio State University in Columbus .	He
At the time , [MASK] was still a proponent of Noam Chomsky 's theory of generative grammar during its earliest transformational grammar phase .	he
In 1963 , his seminal [MASK] The position of embedding transformations in a Grammar introduced the transformational cycle .	article
This [MASK] has been a foundational insight for theories of syntax since that time .	principle
By 1965 , [MASK] had come to acknowledge that semantics plays a crucial role in grammar . [ 6 ]	Fillmore
In 1968 , [MASK] published his theory of Case Grammar ( Fillmore 1968 ) , which highlighted the fact that syntactic structure can be predicted by semantic participants .	he
An [MASK] can have an agent , a patient , purposes , locations , and so on .	action
Following his move to the University of California , Berkeley , in 1971 , this [MASK] eventually evolved into a broader cognitive linguistic theory called Frame Semantics ( 1976 ) .	theory
A commercial [MASK] , for instance , crucially involved elements such as a seller , a buyer , some good , and some money .	event
Around the same time , Fillmore 's Santa Cruz [MASK] on Deixis , delivered in 1971 and published in 1975 , contributed to establishing the field of linguistic pragmatics , which studies the relationship between linguistic form and the context of utterance . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]	Lectures
In all of this research , [MASK] illuminated the fundamental importance of semantics , and its role in motivating syntactic and morphological phenomena .	he
This [MASK] aimed at developing a complete theory of grammar that would fully acknowledge the role of semantics right from the start , while simultaneously adopting constraint - based formalisms as popular in computer science and natural language processing .	work
This [MASK] built on the notion of construction from traditional and pedagogical grammars rather than the rule - based formalisms that dominate most of generative grammar .	theory
[MASK] of Fillmore 's most widely noticed works of the time ( with Paul Kay and Cathy O'Connor ) appeared in ' Language ' in 1988 as " Regularity and Idiomaticity in Grammatical Constructions : The Case of Let Alone " .	One
Their [MASK] highlighted the merits of such a theory of by focusing on the ' let alone ' construction .	paper
Over time , construction [MASK] developed into a research area of its own , and a number of variants have been proposed over the years by different researchers .	grammar
The first [MASK] of  Cognitive Linguistics  by Cruse and Croft ( 2004 ) , for instance , begins with a summary of Fillmore 's work .	chapter
[MASK] served as President of the Linguistic Society of America in 1991 and was awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Chicago in 2000 . [ 7 ]	Fillmore
His [MASK] continues with his many notable students , including Adele Goldberg , Laura Michaelis , Christopher Johnson , Miriam R. L. Petruck , Len Talmy , and Eve Sweetser .	legacy
In the 1990s , [MASK] taught classes in computational lexicography at the University of Pisa , where he met Sue Atkins , who was conducting frame - semantic analyses from a lexicographic perspective .	Fillmore
In their subsequent discussions and collaborations , [MASK] came to acknowledge the importance of considering corpus data . [ 2 ]	Fillmore
[MASK] discussed the " dictionary of the future " , in which every word would be linked to example sentences from corpora . [ 7 ] [ 9 ]	They
After 23 years at the University of California , Berkeley , [MASK] retired in 1994 and joined Berkeley 's International Computer Science Institute . [ 6 ]	Fillmore
There , [MASK] started a project called FrameNet , an on - line structured description of the English lexicon implementing much of what he had earlier proposed more theoretically in his theory of Frame semantics , while implementing the idea of emphasizing example sentences from corpora .	he
[MASK] Poisson reviewed Galois ' paper on equation theory and declared it " incomprehensible " .	Simon
[MASK] returned to mathematics after his expulsion from the cole Normale , although he continued to spend time in political activities .	Galois
After his expulsion became official in January 1831 , [MASK] attempted to start a private class in advanced algebra which attracted some interest , but this waned , as it seemed that his political activism had priority . [ 4 ] [ 7 ]	he
[MASK] Poisson asked him to submit his work on the theory of equations , which he did on 17 January 1831 .	Simon
Around 4 July 1831 , [MASK] declared Galois ' work " incomprehensible " , declaring that " [ Galois ' ] argument is neither sufficiently clear nor sufficiently developed to allow us to judge its rigor " ; however , the rejection report ends on an encouraging note : " We would then suggest that the author should publish the whole of his work in order to form a definitive opinion . " [ 16 ]	Poisson
While Poisson 's report was made before Galois ' July 14 arrest , [MASK] took until October to reach Galois in prison .	it
Apparently , however , [MASK] did not ignore Poisson 's advice , as he began collecting all his mathematical manuscripts while still in prison , and continued polishing his ideas until his release on 29 April 1832 , [ 12 ] after which he was somehow talked into a duel . [ 8 ]	Galois
Galois ' fatal [MASK] took place on 30 May . [ 17 ]	duel
The true [MASK] behind the duel are obscure .	motives
What is known is that five days before his death , [MASK] wrote a letter to Chevalier which clearly alludes to a broken love affair . [ 7 ]	he
Some archival [MASK] on the original letters suggests that the woman of romantic interest was a Mademoiselle Stphanie - Flicie Poterin du Motel , [ 18 ] the daughter of the physician at the hostel where Galois stayed during the last months of his life .	investigation
[MASK] of letters from her , copied by Galois himself ( with many portions , such as her name , either obliterated or deliberately omitted ) , are available . [ 19 ]	Fragments
The [MASK] hint that Mlle. du Motel had confided some of her troubles to Galois , and this might have prompted him to provoke the duel himself on her behalf .	letters
Galois ' [MASK] , Gabriel Demante , when asked if he knew the cause of the duel , mentioned that Galois " found himself in the presence of a supposed uncle and a supposed fianc , each of whom provoked the duel . "	cousin
[MASK] himself famously exclaimed : " I am the victim of an infamous coquette and her two dupes . " [ 12 ]	Galois
As to his opponent in the duel , [MASK] Dumas names Pescheux d'Herbinville , [ 13 ] who was actually one of the nineteen artillery officers whose acquittal was celebrated at the banquet that occasioned Galois ' first arrest . [ 20 ]	Alexandre
However , [MASK] is alone in this assertion , and if he were correct it is unclear why d'Herbinville would have been involved .	Dumas
On the other hand , extant newspaper [MASK] from only a few days after the duel give a description of his opponent ( identified by the initials " L. D. " ) that appear to more accurately apply to one of Galois ' Republican friends , most probably Ernest Duchatelet , who was imprisoned with Galois on the same charges . [ 21 ]	clippings
[MASK] Hermann Weyl said of this testament , " This letter , if judged by the novelty and profundity of ideas it contains , is perhaps the most substantial piece of writing in the whole literature of mankind . "	Mathematician
However , the [MASK] of Galois pouring his mathematical thoughts onto paper the night before he died seems to have been exaggerated . [ 7 ]	legend
In these final papers , [MASK] outlined the rough edges of some work he had been doing in analysis and annotated a copy of the manuscript submitted to the Academy and other papers .	he
[MASK] died the following morning [ 17 ] at ten o'clock in the Hpital Cochin ( probably of peritonitis ) , after refusing the offices of a priest .	He
His [MASK] ended in riots . [ 17 ]	funeral
[MASK] was 20 years old .	He
[MASK] ai besoin de tout mon courage pour mourir  vingt ans ! 	J'
[MASK] need all my courage to die at twenty ! )	I
[MASK] William Goode ( born 3 April 1978 ) is an English character actor .	Matthew
[MASK] made his screen debut in 2002 with ABC 's TV film feature Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister .	He
His breakthrough [MASK] was in the romantic comedy , Chasing Liberty ( 2004 ) , for which he received a nomination at Teen Choice Awards for Choice Breakout Movie Star - Male .	role
[MASK] then appeared in a string of supporting roles in films like Woody Allen 's Match Point ( 2005 ) , the German - British romantic comedy Imagine Me and You ( 2006 ) , and the period drama Copying Beethoven ( 2006 ) .	He
[MASK] 's garnered praise for his performance as Charles Ryder in Julian Jarrold s adaptation of Evelyn Waugh 's Brideshead Revisited ( 2008 ) , and as Ozymandias in the American neo - noir superhero film Watchmen ( 2009 ) , based on DC Comics ' limited series of the same name .	He
[MASK] then starred in romantic comedy Leap Year ( 2010 ) and Australian drama Burning Man ( 2011 ) , the latter earning him a nomination for Best Actor at the Film Critics Circle of Australia Awards .	He
Other notable film [MASK] include The Lookout ( 2007 ) , A Single Man ( 2009 ) , Cemetery Junction ( 2010 ) , Stoker ( 2013 ) , Belle ( 2013 ) , The Imitation Game ( 2014 ) and Self/less ( 2015 ) .	roles
As well as appearing in films , [MASK] has appeared in numerous television shows .	Goode
His most notable television [MASK] include Henry Talbot in the final season of historical period drama Downton Abbey , and Finley " Finn " Polmar in the CBS legal drama The Good Wife .	roles
[MASK] also had a lead role in the critically acclaimed British mini-serial Dancing on the Edge , as music journalist Stanley Mitchell , for which he earned a nomination for Best Actor in a Miniseries or a Television Film at the Satellite Awards .	He
In 2017 , [MASK] portrayed Antony Armstrong - Jones , 1st Earl of Snowdon in the Netflix biographical drama series The Crown , for which he received a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Guest Star in a Drama Series . [ 2 ]	Goode
[MASK] currently stars in Sky One 's fantasy - romance series , A Discovery of Witches , as Professor Matthew Clairmont and is filming Matthew Vaughn 's Kingsman prequel , The King 's Man .	He
[MASK] has been in a relationship with Sophie Dymoke since 2005 .	Goode
[MASK] married in 2014 . [ 17 ] [ 18 ] [ 19 ]	They
[MASK] have two daughters , Matilda Eve Goode [ 3 ] ( b. March 2009 ) and Teddie Eleanor Rose Goode ( b. September 2013 ) , and a son , Ralph Goode ( b. August 2015 ) .	They
[MASK] played Peter Lynley , the brother of Inspector Lynley in the BBC production Inspector Lynley Mysteries : A Suitable Vengeance and co-starred in the TV film Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister , based on the Gregory Maguire novel of the same name and William Shakespeare 's play The Tempest .	Goode
In 2004 , [MASK] made his American film debut opposite Mandy Moore in the romantic comedy Chasing Liberty .	Goode
His [MASK] , Anthony , was a geologist and his mother , Jennifer , is a nurse and amateur theatre director .	father
[MASK] is the youngest of five children with a brother , two half - brothers , and a half - sister , television presenter Sally Meen , from his mother 's previous marriage .	Goode
[MASK] grew up in the village of Clyst St. Mary , near Exeter . [ 3 ]	He
[MASK] Leopold Gordon of Auchleuchries ( 31 March 1635 in Auchleuchries , Aberdeenshire , Scotland  29 November 1699 in Moscow , Russia ) was a general and rear admiral in Russia , of Scottish origin .	Patrick
As a result of his distinguished service for Sweden , Poland and Russia [MASK] rose in ranks from trooper to full general , and became principal advisor and close friend of Tsar Peter the Great .	he
[MASK] assumed the additional Christian name of Leopold when confirmed as a Roman Catholic shortly before his death .	Gordon
After an education at the parish schools of Cruden and Ellon , at age of fifteen [MASK] entered the Jesuit college at Braunsberg , East Prussia , then part of Poland ; however , his character did not tolerate well the strict and sombre way of life at the school , and he soon decided to return home .	he
[MASK] changed his mind , however , before re-embarking on the journey back to Scotland , and after journeying on foot in several parts of what is today Germany , in 1655 he enlisted at Hamburg into the military service of Sweden .	He
In the course of the next five years [MASK] served alternately for Poland and Sweden and was taken prisoner by both .	he
Upon hearing of the Stuart restoration , [MASK] left the Polish service , but found himself unable to obtain military employment in Scotland or England . [ 1 ]	Gordon
In 1661 , after further experiences as a soldier of fortune , [MASK] joined the Russian army under Tsar Aleksei I , and in 1665 was sent on a special mission to England .	he
After his return [MASK] distinguished himself in several wars against the Turks and Tatars in southern Russia .	he
[MASK] disliked the Russian service , complaining of the corruption and venality of Russian officials , which left him , in his own words , " almost at wit s end with vexation " . [ 2 ]	Gordon
[MASK] was not the only Scottish soldier in the Tsar 's service ; his fellow - Scots Paul Menzies and Alexander Livingston also found themselves in Russia fleeing religious intolerance or seeking adventure .	He
[MASK] visited England and Scotland in 1686 .	Gordon
In 1687 and 1689 [MASK] took part in expeditions against the Tatars in the Crimea , being made a full general .	he
Later in 1689 a [MASK] broke out in Moscow , and with the troops under his command Gordon virtually decided events in favour of Peter the Great , [ 3 ] and against the Regent , Tsarevna Sophia Alekseyevna .	revolution
Consequently , [MASK] was for the remainder of his life in high favour with the Tsar , who confided to him the command of his capital during his absence from Russia .	he
In 1696 , Gordon 's [MASK] of a " moveable rampart " played a key role in helping the Russians take Azov . [ 3 ]	design
[MASK] of Gordon 's greatest achievements was securing permission from the Tsars to establish the first Roman Catholic church and school in Muscovy , of which he remained the main benefactor , and headed the Catholic community in Russia until his death .	One
The [MASK] employed him in organizing his army according to the West European system ; and raised him to the rank of full general .	Tsar
At the end of his life the [MASK] , who had visited Gordon frequently during his illness , was with him when he died , and with his own hands closed his eyes .	Tsar
[MASK] Gordon left behind him a uniquely detailed diary of his life and times , written in English .	General
[MASK] lived until 1739 . [ 4 ]	She
[MASK] Zaha Mohammad Hadid DBE RA ( Arabic :   Zah add ; 31 October 1950  31 March 2016 ) was an Iraqi - British architect .	Dame
[MASK] was the first woman to receive the Pritzker Architecture Prize , in 2004 .	She
[MASK] received the UK 's most prestigious architectural award , the Stirling Prize , in 2010 and 2011 .	She
Her major [MASK] include the aquatic centre for the London 2012 Olympics , Michigan State University 's Broad Art Museum in the US , and the Guangzhou Opera House in China .	works
Her [MASK] Mohammed Hadid Muhammad al - Hajj Husayn Hadid was a wealthy industrialist from Mosul .	father
[MASK] co-founded the left - liberal al - Ahali group in 1932 , a significant political organisation in the 1930s and 1940s .	He
[MASK] was the co-founder of the National Democratic Party in Iraq .	He
[MASK] served as minister of finance after the overthrow of the monarch after the 1958 Iraqi coup d'tat for the government of General Abd al - Karim Qasim .	He
Her [MASK] Wajiha al - Sabunji was an artist from Mosul .	mother
In the 1960s [MASK] attended boarding schools in England and Switzerland .	Hadid
[MASK] studied mathematics at the American University of Beirut before moving , in 1972 , to London to study at the Architectural Association School of Architecture .	Hadid
There [MASK] studied with Rem Koolhaas , Elia Zenghelis and Bernard Tschumi .	she
Her former [MASK] , Koolhaas , described her at graduation as " a planet in her own orbit . "	professor
[MASK] described her as the most outstanding pupil he ever taught .	Zenghelis
" [MASK] called her the inventor of the 89 degrees .	We
[MASK] was ever at 90 degrees .	Nothing
[MASK] had spectacular vision .	She
All the [MASK] were exploding into tiny little pieces . "	buildings
[MASK] recalled that she was less interested in details , such as staircases .	He
" The way she drew a staircase [MASK] would smash your head against the ceiling , and the space was reducing and reducing , and you would end up in the upper corner of the ceiling .	you
[MASK] could nt care about tiny details .	She
Her [MASK] was on the broader pictures 	mind
when it came to the joinery [MASK] knew we could fix that later .	she
[MASK] was right . 	She
Her fourth - year student [MASK] was a painting of a hotel in the form of a bridge , inspired by the works of the Russian suprematist artist Kazimir Malevich	project
[MASK] Higuchi (   Higuchi Ichiy , May 2 , 1872  November 23 , 1896 ) was a pen name of Japanese author Natsu Higuchi (   Higuchi Natsu ) , also known as Natsuko Higuchi (   Higuchi Natsuko ) .	Ichiy
Specializing in short stories , [MASK] was one of the first important writers to appear in the Meiji period ( 1868 - 1912 ) and Japan 's first prominent woman writer of modern times .	she
[MASK] wrote relatively little as a result of living a brief life  she died at 24  but her stories had a large impact on Japanese literature and she is still appreciated by the Japanese public today .	She
[MASK] , her mother , and younger sister made ends meet by doing needlework , washing , and other jobs .	She
In 1892 , after seeing the success of a classmate , Kaho Tanabe , who wrote a novel , [MASK] decided to become a novelist to support her family .	Higuchi
Nevertheless , her initial [MASK] at writing fiction were in the form of a short story , a form to which she would remain true .	efforts
In 1891 [MASK] met her future advisor who would help , she assumed , this poet - turned - fiction - writer and connect her with editors : Tosui Nakarai .	she
[MASK] fell in love with him right away , not knowing that , at 31 , he had a reputation as a womanizer .	She
Nor did [MASK] realize that he wrote popular literature which aimed to please the general public and in no way wished to be associated with serious literature .	she
Her [MASK] did not return her passionate , if discreet , love for him , and instead treated her as a younger sister .	mentor
This failed [MASK] would become a recurrent theme in Higuchi 's fiction .	relationship
Eventually , [MASK] got the break she was so eager for :	she
The [MASK] from this first period ( 1892  94 ) suffered from the excessive influence of Heian poetry .	stories
