Once it got started , [MASK] realised that the idea must have been inspired by the title of Justine Larbalestier s How to Ditch Your Fairy , although it has nothing at all to do with that story at all .	I
All in all , my [MASK] feels very light .	story
But [MASK] think I needed something a little less dark , and there are some quite sombre tales coming up in the coming weeks .	I
 [MASK] have already told you of the sickness and confusion that comes with time travelling .	I
For an indefinite time [MASK] clung to the machine as it swayed and vibrated , quite unheeding how I went , and when I brought myself to look at the dials again I was amazed to find where I had arrived .	I
One [MASK] records days , and another thousands of days , another millions of days , and another thousands of millions .	dial
Now , instead of reversing the levers , [MASK] had pulled them over so as to go forward with them , and when I came to look at these indicators I found that the thousands hand was sweeping round as fast as the seconds hand of a watch  into futurity .	I
 As I drove on , a peculiar [MASK] crept over the appearance of things .	change
The palpitating [MASK] grew darker ; then  though I was still travelling with prodigious velocity  the blinking succession of day and night , which was usually indicative of a slower pace , returned , and grew more and more marked .	greyness
[MASK] puzzled me very much at first .	This
The [MASK] of night and day grew slower and slower , and so did the passage of the sun across the sky , until they seemed to stretch through centuries .	alternations
At last a steady [MASK] brooded over the earth , a twilight only broken now and then when a comet glared across the darkling sky .	twilight
The [MASK] of light that had indicated the sun had long since disappeared ; for the sun had ceased to set  it simply rose and fell in the west , and grew ever broader and more red .	band
All [MASK] of the moon had vanished .	trace
The [MASK] of the stars , growing slower and slower , had given place to creeping points of light .	circling
At last , some time before I stopped , the [MASK] , red and very large , halted motionless upon the horizon , a vast dome glowing with a dull heat , and now and then suffering a momentary extinction .	sun
At one time [MASK] had for a little while glowed more brilliantly again , but it speedily reverted to its sullen red heat .	it
[MASK] perceived by this slowing down of its rising and setting that the work of the tidal drag was done .	I
The [MASK] had come to rest with one face to the sun , even as in our own time the moon faces the earth .	earth
Very cautiously , for I remembered my former headlong fall , [MASK] began to reverse my motion .	I
 [MASK] stopped very gently and sat upon the Time Machine , looking round .	I
The [MASK] was no longer blue .	sky
North - eastward [MASK] was inky black , and out of the blackness shone brightly and steadily the pale white stars .	it
Overhead [MASK] was a deep Indian red and starless , and south - eastward it grew brighter to a glowing scarlet where , cut by the horizon , lay the huge hull of the sun , red and motionless .	it
The [MASK] about me were of a harsh reddish colour , and all the trace of life that I could see at first was the intensely green vegetation that covered every projecting point on their south - eastern face .	rocks
[MASK] was the same rich green that one sees on forest moss or on the lichen in caves : plants which like these grow in a perpetual twilight .	It
 The [MASK] was standing on a sloping beach .	machine
The [MASK] stretched away to the south - west , to rise into a sharp bright horizon against the wan sky .	sea
Only a slight oily [MASK] rose and fell like a gentle breathing , and showed that the eternal sea was still moving and living .	swell
The [MASK] reminded me of my only experience of mountaineering , and from that I judged the air to be more rarefied than it is now .	sensation
 Far away up the desolate slope [MASK] heard a harsh scream , and saw a thing like a huge white butterfly go slanting and fluttering up into the sky and , circling , disappear over some low hillocks beyond .	I
The [MASK] of its voice was so dismal that I shivered and seated myself more firmly upon the machine .	sound
Looking round me again , [MASK] saw that , quite near , what I had taken to be a reddish mass of rock was moving slowly towards me .	I
Then [MASK] saw the thing was really a monstrous crab - like creature .	I
Can [MASK] imagine a crab as large as yonder table , with its many legs moving slowly and uncertainly , its big claws swaying , its long antenn , like carters  whips , waving and feeling , and its stalked eyes gleaming at you on either side of its metallic front ?	you
Its [MASK] was corrugated and ornamented with ungainly bosses , and a greenish incrustation blotched it here and there .	back
[MASK] could see the many palps of its complicated mouth flickering and feeling as it moved .	I
[MASK] stayed with me that night , lying next to me in my blankets and furs .	Veronique
She did n't sleep , [MASK] do n't think .	I
[MASK] was listening to her breath .	I
[MASK] felt as if I should help her sleep .	I
[MASK] lay there and tried to think if I should put my arm around her , but I did n't know .	I
Maybe [MASK] did n't want to be touched .	she
And [MASK] had been a stupid girl , anyway .	she
[MASK] lay tense in the dark .	She
" Are you going to be a teacher ? " [MASK] asked .	I
[MASK] laughed .	She
" If [MASK] get out of here . "	I
[MASK] waited for her to say more , but she did n't .	I
Maybe [MASK] meant if she made herself .	she
" You come here from Earth ? " [MASK] asked .	I
" My family came here from Earth , " [MASK] said .	she
" My father , he 's an anthropologist , " [MASK] said .	she
" Do [MASK] know anthropologist ? "	you
" No , " [MASK] said .	I
" [MASK] is a person who studies the way people live .	He
And [MASK] is a teacher . "	he
All the [MASK] I had ever met were teachers .	offworlders
[MASK] wondered who did all the work on Earth .	I
" Because Earth had lost touch with your world , the people here are very interesting to my father , " [MASK] said .	she
Her [MASK] was listless in the dark and she was even harder to understand when I could n't see her properly .	voice
[MASK] did n't understand so I did n't say anything .	I
[MASK] was sorry I 'd started her talking .	I
" History , do you know the word ' history ' ? " [MASK] asked .	she
Of course [MASK] knew the word " history . "	I
" I study history in school , " [MASK] said .	I
[MASK] and Kumar taught it .	Anneal
" Do [MASK] know the history of this world ? "	you
" Yes , " [MASK] said .	I
" [MASK] are a colony .	We
[MASK] from Earth come here to live .	People
[MASK] forget we are from Earth .	We
Then [MASK] finds us again . "	Earth
" Some people have stories about coming from the Earth , " [MASK] said .	Veronique
" My [MASK] is collecting those stories from different peoples .	father
[MASK] 'm a graduate student . "	I
The [MASK] did n't have any stories about coming from Earth .	clans
[MASK] said the first people came out of the sun .	We
[MASK] somehow seemed embarrassing .	This
[MASK] did n't understand what kind of student she was .	I
" Are you here for stories ? " [MASK] asked .	I
" No , " [MASK] said .	she
" [MASK] is old friends with your teacher , from back when they were both with the survey .	Ian
[MASK] just came to visit . "	We
[MASK] did n't understand what she 'd said except that they were visiting .	I
[MASK] were quiet after that .	We
[MASK] pretended to sleep .	I
[MASK] fell asleep thinking about how I wished that the Scathalos outrunners were gone .	I
[MASK] dreamed that I was at the offworlder 's home , where it was summer but no one was taking care of the stabros , and they were all glad , and so I was a hero - and I was startled awake by gunfire .	I
[MASK] wished my da would come home .	I
The Chemical [MASK] by Christian Rosencreutz is the way I ve decided to present the title of this book .	Wedding
[MASK] s not ; Christian Rosencreutz is the purported author of a book called The Chemical Wedding .	It
The actual [MASK] is Johann Valentin Andreae , whose name did nt appear on the book originally , thus ensuring the confusion .	author
[MASK] ll call it herein ( as everyone mostly does ) simply The Chemical Wedding .	I
[MASK] might therefore wish to start right in on the first page of text that follows and only then return to this introduction .	You
[MASK] was just before Easter Sunday , 1 and I was sitting at my table .	It
[MASK] d said my prayers , talking a long time as usual with my Maker and thinking about some of the great mysteries the Father of Lights had revealed to me .	I
Now [MASK] was ready to make and to bake  only in my heart , actually  a small , perfect unleavened wafer to eat with my beloved Paschal Lamb .	I
All of a sudden a terrible [MASK] blew up , so strong that I thought the hill my little house was built on would be blown apart  but I d seen the Devil do things as bad as this before ( the Devil had often tried to harm me ) , so I took heart and went on meditating .	wind
Till [MASK] felt somebody touch me on the back .	I
[MASK] frightened me so that I did nt dare turn .	This
[MASK] tried to stay as brave and calm as a human being could under the circumstances .	I
[MASK] felt my coat tugged at , and tugged again , and at last I looked around .	I
A [MASK] stood there , so bright and beautiful , in a sky - colored robe  a heavens covered with	woman
1 Christian s [MASK] begins just before Easter , like Dante s Divine Comedy .	story
The [MASK] sang so beautifully , the young deer skipped so happily , that it gladdened my old heart , and I could n't help singing too ...	birds
[MASK] was awake and lying in bed next morning , looking idly at the wonderful images and inscriptions all around my room , when suddenly I heard the sound of trumpets , as if a procession were already underway .	I
My [MASK] jumped out of bed as if crazed , looking more dead than alive , and you can imagine how I felt when he cried ,  They 're already being presented to the king ! "	page
[MASK] could only groan in frustration and curse my lazy bones .	I
[MASK] soon came back and gave me the good news that I actually had nt overslept ; all I d done was miss breakfast : they had nt wanted to wake an old man who needed his rest .	He
But now [MASK] had to get ready to go with him to the lion fountain , where most of the others were gathered .	I
My [MASK] recovered , and as soon as I had got into my habit , I followed him to the garden I have already told about .	spirits
[MASK] found that the lion , in place of his sword , now held a rather large plaque .	I
Examining this , [MASK] could tell that it had been taken from those ancient monuments I d seen and put here for some special reason .	I
The [MASK] on it was fading away , so I should set it down here as it was then , and ask my readers to ponder it :	inscription
[MASK] Nick Bos tells Wikinews about ' self - medicating ' ants	Biologist
[MASK] Bos , of the University of Helsinki , studies " the amazing adaptations social insects have evolved in order to fight the extreme parasite pressure they experience " .	Nick
In a recently - accepted Evolution paper [MASK] and colleagues describe ants appearing to self - medicate .	Bos
" [MASK] have no doubt that as time goes on , there will be more and more cases documented "	I
The [MASK] used Formica fusca , an ant species that can form thousand - strong colonies .	team
This common black [MASK] eats other insects , and also aphid honeydew .	ant
[MASK] often nests in tree stumps or under rocks and foraging workers can sometimes be spotted climbing trees .	It
Infected [MASK] chose food laced with toxic hydrogen peroxide , whereas healthy ants avoided it .	ants
Hydrogen [MASK] reduced infected ant fatalities by 15 % , and the ants varied their intake depending upon how high the peroxide concentration was .	peroxide
In the wild , Formica [MASK] can encounter similar chemicals in aphids and dead ants .	fusca
The [MASK] reported self - medicating ants a first among insects .	Independent
[MASK] obtained his doctorate from the University of Copenhagen .	Bos
[MASK] began postdoctoral research at Helsinki in 2012 .	He
[MASK] also runs the AntyScience blog .	He
The [MASK] aims to help address " a gap between scientists and ' the general public ' . "	blog
The [MASK] is a pun referencing ants , its primary topic , science , and " non-scientific " jargon - free communication .	name
[MASK] now discusses his work with Wikinews .	He
[MASK] first attracted you to researching ants ?	What
[MASK] and a studymate were keeping a lot of animals during our studies , from beetles , to butterflies and mantids , to ants .	Me
[MASK] had the ants in an observation nest , and I could just look at them for hours , watching them go about .	We
This was in my third year of Biology study [MASK] think .	I
After a while [MASK] needed to start thinking about an internship for my M.Sc. studies , and decided to write a couple of professors .	I
[MASK] ended up going to the Centre for Social Evolution at the University of Copenhagen where I did a project on learning in Ants under supervision of Prof. Patrizia d'Ettorre .	I
[MASK] liked it so much there I ended up doing a PhD and I 've been working on social insects ever since .	I
[MASK] is a fun one .	This
[MASK] try to work on a very low budget , and like to build most of the experimental setups myself ( we actually have equipment in the lab nicknamed the ' Nickinator ' , ' i-Nick ' and the ' Nicktendo64 ' ) .	I
[MASK] collected wild colonies of Formica fusca by searching through old tree - trunks in old logging sites in southern Finland .	We
[MASK] then housed the ants in nests I made using Y - tong [ aerated concrete ] .	We
[MASK] 's very soft stone that you can easily carve .	It
[MASK] carved out little squares for the ants to live in ( covered with old CD covers to prevent them escaping ! ) .	We
[MASK] then drilled a tunnel to a pot ( the foraging arena ) , where the ants got the choice between the food with medicine and the food without .	We
[MASK] infected the ants by preparing a solution of the fungus Beauveria bassiana .	We
After exposing the ants to the fungus , [MASK] took pictures of each foraging arena three times per day , and counted how many ants were present on each food - source .	we
[MASK] gave us the data that ants choose more medicine after they have been infected .	This
For this [MASK] basically put colonies on a diet of either food with medicine or without for a while .	we
Then for about two weeks [MASK] count every day how many ants died .	we
[MASK] gives us the data to do a so - called survival analysis .	This
[MASK] measured the ROS - concentration in the bodies of ants after they ingested the food with the medicine using a spectrophotometer .	We
The detrimental [MASK] of ROS on spores was easy to measure .	effect
[MASK] mixed different concentrations of ROS with the spores , plated them out on petri dishes with an agar - solution where fungus can grow on .	We
A day after , [MASK] counted how many spores were still alive .	we
How reliable do [MASK] consider your results to be ?	you
The [MASK] we got are very reliable .	results
[MASK] had a lot of colonies containing a lot of ants , and wherever possible we conducted the experiment blind .	We
[MASK] means the experimenter does n't know which ants belong to which treatment , so it 's impossible to influence the results with ' observer bias ' .	This
However , of course [MASK] is proof in just one species .	this
[MASK] interviews President of the International Brotherhood of Magicians	Wikinews
[MASK] is National Magic Month in the United States .	October
[MASK] spoke with William Evans , president of the International Brotherhood of Magicians , about the current state of magic and what its future looks like in the world of entertainment .	Wikinews
[MASK] am 61 now so I really started when I was about 10 years old even though I had seen and worked with some basic tricks a few years earlier .	I
[MASK] remember going into Hollywood Magic and wanting that big red box with the dragons on it and I did n't even know what it did .	I
The [MASK] behind the counter was wise enough not to sell it to me , but instead sold me two books which I still own today - " Scarne on Card Tricks " and " Scarne on Magic Tricks " .	magician
[MASK] started me out on books and I have amassed quite a few since then .	That
My major [MASK] on performance are Eugene Burger and Michael Skinner .	influences
[MASK] is National Magic Month in the US .	October
Do [MASK] think magic is alive as a viable form of entertainment today ?	you
Has the [MASK] helped or hurt magic ?	internet
[MASK] think it has helped draw younger people to magic as a hobby , but I think it has hurt the ability of young magicians to think because so many rely on the internet for everything and they are n't reading the books .	I
[MASK] have to have knowledge of the history of magic and what has been done before .	We
[MASK] can become a monkey ; it takes serious study to become a magician .	Anyone
Do [MASK] travel much in your current role ?	you
Yes , [MASK] am traveling quite a bit .	I
After I was inducted as International President in Phoenix in July , [MASK] have been to the Jeff McBride Experience in Eureka Springs , Arkansas , Magic Live in Las Vegas , The Midwest Magic Jubilee in St. Louis , the TAOM in Dallas , the British Ring Convention in Buxton , England and the Magic Circle in London .	I
[MASK] am going to Las Vegas and Los Angeles next month , Italy in November , back to Las Vegas in December , Mexico in January , Magi - Fest in February , the Winter Carnival of Magic in Tennessee in March , Eureka Springs Cavalcade of Magic in March , and the FFFF in April .	I
[MASK] 's as of now .	That
[MASK] Chomsky is a professor emeritus at Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Linguistics and Philosophy .	Noam
[MASK] was one of the first opponents of the Vietnam War , and is a self - described Libertarian Socialist .	He
At age 80 [MASK] continues to write books ; his latest book , Hegemony or Survival , was a bestseller in non-fiction .	he
According to the Arts and Humanities Citation Index [MASK] Chomsky is the eighth most cited scholar of all time .	Professor
On March 13 , [MASK] Chomsky sat down with Michael Dranove for an interview in his MIT office in Cambridge , Massachusetts .	Professor
[MASK] just wanted to know if you had any thoughts on recent NATO actions and the protests coming up at the 60th NATO conference , I know you re speaking at the counter-conference .	I
On the NATO conference , well I mean the obvious question is why should [MASK] exist ?	NATO
In fact [MASK] can ask questions about why it should ever have existed , but now why should it exist .	you
I mean the theory was , whether you believe it or not , that [MASK] would be a defensive alliance against potential Soviet aggression , that s the basic doctrine .	it
The agreement was that [MASK] agreed to a quite remarkable concession : he agreed to let a united Germany join the NATO military alliance .	Gorbachev
Now [MASK] is remarkable in the light of history , the history of the past century , Germany alone had virtually destroyed Russia , twice , and Germany backed by a hostile military alliance , centered in the most phenomenal military power in history , that s a real threat .	it
Nevertheless [MASK] agreed , but there was a quid pro quo , namely that NATO should not expand to the east , so Russia would at least have a kind of security zone .	he
And [MASK] Bush and James Baker , secretary of state , agreed that NATO would not expand one inch to the east .	George
[MASK] also proposed a nuclear free weapons zone in the region , but the U.S would nt consider that .	Gorbachev
Okay , so [MASK] was the basis on which then shortly after the Soviet Union collapsed .	that
Well , [MASK] came into office what did he do ?	Clinton
Well [MASK] s a significant threat to the Soviet Union , to Russia now that there was no longer any Soviet Union , it was a significant threat to Russia and not surprisingly they responded by beefing up their offensive capacity , not much but some .	that
So [MASK] rescinded their pledge not to use nuclear weapons on first strike , NATO had never rescinded it , but they had and started some remilitarization .	they
With Bush , the aggressive [MASK] of the Bush administration , as predicted , induced Russia to extend further its offensive military capacity ; it s still going on right now .	militarism
When Bush proposed the missile defense systems in Eastern Europe , Poland and Czechoslovakia , [MASK] was a real provocation to the Soviet Union .	it
And the claim was that [MASK] had to do with Iranian missiles , but forget about that .	it
And the head of NATO , Hoop Scheffer , [MASK] has explained that NATO must take on responsibility for ensuring the security of pipelines and sea lanes , that is NATO must be a guarantor of energy supplies for the West .	he
Well [MASK] s kind of an unending war , so do we want NATO to exist , do we want there to be a Western military alliance that carries out these activities , with no pretense of defense ?	that
Well [MASK] think that s a pretty good question ; I do nt see why it should , I mean there happens to be no other military alliance remotely comparable  if there happened to be one I d be opposed to that too .	I
So [MASK] think the first question is , what is this all about , why should we even be debating NATO , is there any reason why it should exist ?	I
[MASK] ve seen mass strikes all around the world , in countries that we would nt expect it .	We
Do [MASK] think this is a revival of the Left in the West ?	you
Or do [MASK] think it s nothing ?	you
[MASK] s really hard to tell .	It
Sit down [MASK] which began at a significant level in the 1930s were very threatening to management and ownership , because the sit down strike is one step before workers taking over the factory and running it and kicking out the management , and probably doing a better job .	strikes
So [MASK] s a frightening idea , and police were called in and so on .	that
Well [MASK] just had one in the United States at the Republic Windows and Doors Factory , it s hard to know , I mean these things are just hard to predict , they may take off , and they may take on a broader scope , they may fizzle away or be diverted .	we
[MASK] interviews New York bar owner on Santorum cocktail	Wikinews
[MASK] interviewed one of the owners of a New York City bar about a popular new politically - themed cocktail drink called Santorum .	Wikinews
Savage 's [MASK] voted to define santorum as ; " the frothy mixture of lube and fecal matter that is sometimes the byproduct of anal sex . "	readers
The santorum [MASK] has inspired satirical forms of parody , including this political cartoon by Saturday Morning Breakfast Cereal webcomic artist Zach Weiner .	neologism
[MASK] commented on the creation of the Santorum cocktail , " When he was winning in the polls , I thought , ' OK , I 'll do a Santorum ' . "	Stan
Regarding how long the beverage will be made available , [MASK] remarked to The Brooklyn Paper , " We 'll keep it around until he s irrelevant . I hope he s there the whole way " .	Stan
The main [MASK] of the Santorum drink include vodka of an orange citrus variety , Baileys Irish Cream , and Angostura bitters .	ingredients
[MASK] Patterson of Slate Magazine ventured over to Pacific Standard to sample the new santorum cocktail at the bar .	Troy
After tasting the beverage , [MASK] observed , " My Santorum was sweet but balanced , with a subtle citrus pucker " .	Patterson
[ The santorum [MASK] is ] offensive beyond , you know , anything that any public figure or anybody in America should tolerate , and the mainstream media laughs about it .  Rick Santorum	neologism
In a 2003 interview with the Associated Press , [MASK] Santorum compared legalizing same - sex marriage in the United States to supporting bestiality .	Rick
[MASK] of the Savage Love advice column selected a new definition for the Senator s last name , and Savage created a website SpreadingSantorum.com to promulgate the spread of the phenomenon .	Readers
The [MASK] became a prominent result in searches online , and gained dominance on Web search engines including Google , Bing , and Yahoo! .	term
[MASK] Santorum himself has acknowledged and discussed the existence and prevalence of the santorum neologism phenomenon ; he was quoted by The Canadian Press on his assessment of Google 's response ;	Rick
[MASK] suspect that 's not true . "	I
[MASK] criticized the response of the press to the phenomenon in a 2011 radio interview , saying , " It 's offensive beyond , you know , anything that any public figure or anybody in America should tolerate , and the mainstream media laughs about it . "	Santorum
Pacific Standard [MASK] , Jonathan M. Stan , displays the Santorum cocktail drink as a finished product at the bar . ( 2012 ) .	owner
[MASK] inspired you to create a cocktail after the santorum neologism ?	What
[MASK] the person has been in the news throughout the primary season , and we thought it would be interesting to try to create a delicious drink that mimicked the appearance of the Dan Savage meaning of " santorum . "	Santorum
How did [MASK] first hear about the definition of the santorum neologism that grew out of the contest from the Savage Love advice column ?	you
[MASK] do n't really remember .	We
[MASK] 's been around forever .	It
[MASK] 'll leave that to the professionals .	We
Do [MASK] think it was an appropriate form of satire for Dan Savage to popularize the definition of the santorum neologism created in his advice column ?	you
[MASK] thought it was funny .	We
What [MASK] go in the Santorum cocktail ?	ingredients
Your Santorum cocktail [MASK] has already received media coverage from publications including ; The Brooklyn Paper , The New York Times , Jezebel , Metro.us , EDGE on the Net , and Instinct Magazine .	creation
Did [MASK] think when you created it that the Santorum cocktail would receive this news coverage ?	you
[MASK] were just trying to come up with a topical and funny new cocktail for our customers to laugh about and enjoy .	We
What culinary dishes would [MASK] recommend that go well with the Santorum cocktail ?	you
[MASK] 'd probably be having the cocktail at dessert time , so something sweet ; ice cream or pie .	You
Is the [MASK] popular ?	drink
How many times do [MASK] suppose you ve served it at your establishment since its creation ?	you
The [MASK] was mildly popular for the last few months , but of course has become a great deal more popular since getting all this publicity .	drink
[MASK] have no way to estimate how many times we 've served it overall , but we 're now pouring around ten a night .	We
How did [MASK] come to be involved with this discovery	you
[MASK] Rack got in touch after they returned from Antarctica in hopes that I could help with an identification on the anemone .	Frank
[MASK] was your first reaction upon learning there was an undiscovered ecosystem under the ice in the Ross Sea ?	What
[MASK] think to say it was unexpected is inaccurate , because it implies that there was a well - founded expectation of something .	I
The [MASK] that Frank and his colleagues are using to explore the ice is so important because , given our lack of data , we have no reasonable expectation of what it should be like , or what it should n't be like .	technology
Are [MASK] intending to go there yourself ?	you
[MASK] would love to .	I
But [MASK] am also happy to not go , as long as someone collects more animals on my behalf !	I
[MASK] I want to do with the animals requires new material preserved in diverse ways , but it does n't require me to be there .	What
Although I am sure that being there would enhance my understanding of the animals and the system in which they live , and would help me formulate more and better questions about the anemones , ship [MASK] is expensive , especially in Antarctica , and if there are biologists whose contribution is predicated on being there , they should have priority to be there .	time
[MASK] of the most intriguing questions are chemical ; do they produce some kind of antifreeze , and is that orange glow in the ROV lights their own ?	Some
The [MASK] we have are small in terms of numbers and they are all preserved in formalin ( a kind of formaldehyde solution ) .	samples
The [MASK] is great for preserving structures , but for anemones , it prevents study of DNA or of the chemistry of the body .	formalin
[MASK] means we ca n't look at the issue you raise with these animals .	This
[MASK] can start that side of the work now , anticipating having more beasts in the future .	We
In terms of their glow , [MASK] suspect that it 's not theirs - although luminescence is common in anemone relatives , they do n't usually make light themselves .	I
[MASK] do make a host of florescent proteins , and these may interact with the light of the ROV to give that gorgeous glow .	They
What analysis did [MASK] perform on the specimens and what equipment was used ?	you
[MASK] used a dissecting scope to look at the animal 's external anatomy and overall body organization ( magnification of 60 X ) .	I
[MASK] embedded a few of the animals in wax and then cut them into very thin slices using a microtome , mounted the slices on microscope slides , stained the slices to enhance contrast , and then looked at those slides under a compound microscope	I
( [MASK] 's how I got the pictures of the muscles etc in the paper ) .	that
[MASK] used that same compound scope to look at squashed bits of tissue to see the stinging capsules ( = nematocysts ) .	I
[MASK] compared the things I saw under the 'scopes to what had been published on other species in this group .	I
This [MASK] seems trivial , but it is really the most important part !	step
By comparing my observations to what my colleagues and predecessors had found , [MASK] figured out what group it belongs to , and was able to determine that within that group , it was a new species .	I
[MASK] was three years between recovery of specimens and final publication , why did it take so long ?	It
[MASK] mean , how did we manage to make it all happen so quickly , right ? :)	You
[MASK] was about two years from when Frank sent me specimens to when we got the paper out .	It
[MASK] of that time was just lost time - I had other projects in the queue that I needed to finish .	Some
Once we figured out what it was , [MASK] played a lot of manuscript email tag , which can be challenging and time consuming given the differing schedules that folks keep in terms of travel , field work , etc.	we
Manuscript [MASK] and processing took about four months .	review
The [MASK] was not unorthodox - they followed best practices for anatomical preservation .	preservation
[MASK] am curious about the population structure of the " fields " of anemones - the group to which Edwardsiella andrillae belongs includes many species that reproduce asexually , and it 's possible that the fields are " clones " produced asexually rather than the result of sexual reproduction .	I
[MASK] is the only way to test this .	DNA

[MASK] explained how she obtained these images of the anemone 's anatomy .	Daly

[MASK] is a wiki - based site which aims to " build the world 's largest , highest quality how - to manual . "	wikiHow
[MASK] recently published its 50,000th article , and to discuss what the site has achieved since its creation , Wikinews interviewed the site 's founder , Jack Herrick .	It
In the interview , [MASK] explains what wikiHow is , why he decided to create it , how he grew it in size , and why he chose to use a Creative Commons license ( HyperLink ) for his site .	Herrick
For our readers who are unaware of your site , could [MASK] briefly explain what wikiHow is ?	you
[MASK] is a collaborative effort to build the world 's largest , highest quality how - to manual .	wikiHow
[MASK] 're quite far from our goals currently , but we take comfort in the fact that every month wikiHow gets noticeably better and larger	We
[MASK] currently have just under 50000 articles and over 1000 featured articles .	We
[MASK] hope that in time , we will have millions of articles with many of them having featured status .	We
That said , [MASK] are realistic enough to realize that this goal will take decades to achieve .	we
However , in terms of readership , [MASK] are probably the most popular single subject wiki after Wikipedia .	we
[MASK] get over 14 million unique visitors per month ( source : Google Analytics ) , which makes us the 135th most popular site according to Quantcast .	We
Like Wikipedia , [MASK] is a wiki that runs on Mediawiki software .	wikiHow
Our [MASK] is full of volunteers from all over the world .	community
That said , [MASK] are quite different from Wikipedia in several respects :	we
[MASK] are much smaller .	We
The English [MASK] has only 60 admins , compared to the 1000 + on English Wikipedia .	wikiHow
As a result , [MASK] is still at the size that every editor eventually gets to know other editors .	wikiHow
[MASK] has several advantages and disadvantages when compared to the non-profit structure at the Wikimedia Foundation .	This
[MASK] show opt - out advertising to anonymous visitors rather than ask for donations .	We
Our advertising [MASK] funds community meetups and has even allowed us to donate over $ 60,000 to charities such as the Wikimedia Foundation and Creative Commons .	revenue
In addition , [MASK] 've used our revenue on things like buying carbon offsets to become carbon neutral .	we
As a result some [MASK] believe wikiHow is a more humane and enjoyable place to work than other places online .	folks
Why did [MASK] decide to create wikiHow ?	you
[MASK] think that providing people with a practical education is one of the most empowering things you can offer a person .	I
How much more could [MASK] accomplish as an individual if you could learn any activity ?	you
[MASK] think that building a universal how - to manual would be a tremendous gift for the world .	I
[MASK] is power and wikiHow has the potential to make all of us a bit more powerful .	Knowledge
[MASK] 've been interested in building a comprehensive how - to manual long before I first envisioned wikiHow .	I
My first [MASK] at building this resource was a website I used to run called eHow .	attempt
[MASK] was and continues to be the largest and how to website in the world .	eHow
[MASK] contains copyrighted content run on proprietary software .	eHow
This business [MASK] worked for producing content on topics that appeal to advertisers in languages like English that have large advertising markets .	model
[MASK] either 1) sacrifice on breadth and do n't produce the topics that wo n't interest advertisers , or 2) you sacrifice on quality and produce content that does n't cost much to write .	You
[MASK] was n't interested in making either of these sacrifices , as I think the world 's how to manual needs to be high quality AND comprehensive .	I
So ultimately [MASK] decided that eHow 's model would not build the resource I envisioned .	I
When I discovered Wikipedia , [MASK] recognized that the wiki model had the potential to build the how - to resource the world really needs .	I
So [MASK] decided to sell eHow and use the proceeds to build wikiHow .	I
Why did [MASK] decide to use a Creative Commons license ?	you
[MASK] use a Creative Commons license to give our community the right to fork ( http://www.wikihow.com/wikiHow:Right-to-Fork ) .	We
In my opinion , [MASK] should be hesitant to contribute to websites where you only have the " right to leave . "	people
If wikiHow volunteers think our site is going in the wrong direction , [MASK] can take all the content and all the software and move the project elsewhere .	they
[MASK] is possible because we release all of our software under the Open Source GPL license and release our content under a Creative Commons license .	This
This [MASK] to fork guarantees that wikiHow , the company , will always serve the goal of the mission and our volunteer community .	right
[MASK] believe that offering this right to fork has been a key element of our success thus far .	I
My hope is that over time , internet [MASK] will demand this of any site where they invest their time in a way that creates value for others .	users
That said , when we started out [MASK] did n't know the difference between the GNU Free Document License and my California Driver 's license .	I
As a result , [MASK] made some mistakes along the path .	we
In retrospect , [MASK] think we probably should have selected the CC BY - SA license instead of CC - BY - SA - NC .	I
At a minimum [MASK] would provide a helpful compatibility with other wikis and free culture projects .	this
[MASK] now has millions of visitors per month .	wikiHow
How did [MASK] grow the site to the size it is today ?	you
In December 2008 , [MASK] had over 14 million unique visitors according to Google Analytics ( Full data : http://www.wikihow.com/wikiHow:Statistics ) .	wikiHow
[MASK] ranks wikiHow as the 135th most popular site in the US .	Quantcast
[MASK] achieved this popularity for a few reasons .	wikiHow
First , [MASK] around the world are desperate for high quality how - to information .	people
[MASK] want to learn more practical skills , and for the most part the internet does n't provide enough quality information yet .	People
Second , [MASK] attracted millions of readers via the virtuous circle of wiki editing : We had some articles of mixed quality , and editors joined to improve those articles , which in turn attracted more readers .	we
[MASK] continue to depend on this same virtuous cycle : More readers , means more editors , which creates better instructions , leading again to more readers .	We
[MASK] is the same virtuous circle that Wikipedia has enjoyed .	It
[MASK] interviews academic Simon Lien about attitudes towards US Paralympics	Wikinews
On Thursday , with 110 days until the start of the 2014 Winter Paralympics in Sochi , Russia , [MASK] interviewed Assistant Professor in Educational Leadership , Sport Studies and Educational / Counseling Psychology at Washington State University Simon Lien about attitudes in United States towards the Paralympics .	Wikinews
[MASK] has recently joined the Sport Management Program at Washington State University to develop its sport media and communication research and teaching contents .	Lien
Originally from Slovenia , [MASK] served as the Director of Media and Communications of a WTA Tour event and was a member of the UNESCO Slovenian National Commission .	he
[MASK] was also the Team Manager of the Slovenian wheelchair basketball national team .	He
Why do [MASK] think the Paralympic movement has so little visibility in the US compared to other countries like Australia , the United Kingdom and even Canada ?	you
[MASK] in the United States largely reaffirm existing relations of power in society .	Sports
[MASK] emphasizes consumerism , the belief that success always goes to people who merit it due to their abilities , dedication and qualifications , and reinforces , rather than changes , existing ideas related to gender , ethnicity and nationality .	It
Paralympic [MASK] brings attention to athletes who are typically overlooked in American society because the majority of the population does not want to identify with people who are disabled .	sport
Although disability is not contagious , [MASK] in disabled sports might put into question the masculinity of the males following it .	interest
Disabled [MASK] also challenge existing relations of power by displaying dedication , hard work and perseverance in different contexts than those most sports fans are accustomed to .	athletes
Other [MASK] , including the ones you mention , have stronger social orientations in all aspects of society .	countries
Even though legislative support may be less strong than the one provided by the Americans with Disabilities Act , many social [MASK] including the media are more receptive to this form of diversity .	institutions
What do [MASK] think the impact will be for the Paralympic movement will be with the Games being televised live in the United States for first time ?	you
The [MASK] depends on a number of aspects .	impact
[MASK] of them is the channels that NBC as the broadcasting rights owner for the United States will use to air the Paralympic Games on .	One
A second [MASK] is the parts or hours of the day the Paralympics will be shown .	aspect
A third important [MASK] is the way the event will be mediated : will NBC have its best sports broadcasters following the event after having worked the Winter Olympics ?	factor
Will [MASK] treat and announce the competitions as they do all others  for better and worse ?	they
Will [MASK] take it as an opportunity to educate viewers about disability and diversity while showing superb athletic performances without engaging in a discourse of pity ?	they
All in all , [MASK] think this is a terrific opportunity to improve sports coverage in a multitude of aspects ; but we will have to wait until after the event to assess to what extent the broadcasters will meet these expectations .	I
The LibriVox [MASK] features a catalog of about a hundred completed books , including books in other languages like German , Hebrew , and Japanese .	website
Why did [MASK] decide to take the acoustic fate of public domain works into your own hands , and how did you go about it ?	you
[MASK] think that a vibrant public domain is very important to a healthy world , and so I thought : here 's a way to help the cause .	I
[MASK] launched LibriVox , emailed some friends and some podcasters who where doing literary stuff , and invited them to record a chapter of Joseph Conrad 's Secret Agent .	I
[MASK] have grown steadily since .	Things
By the way , [MASK] was the first guy I know of to do something like this , with Lawrence Lessig 's Free Culture .	AKMA
[MASK] , I think , started my thinking about this , but it took a while for the idea to crystallize .	That
Do [MASK] personally record audiobooks , and did you already do so before LibriVox ?	you
[MASK] was my first experience recording audiobooks .	LibriVox
[MASK] still do the odd chapter , but i am a bit delinquent in finishing some of them these days !	I
My personal [MASK] is Notes from the Underground ( Dostoyevsky ) .	favourite
Browsing the catalog , [MASK] find that the quality of the spoken audio varies greatly from text to text or even from chapter to chapter .	I
If someone wanted to re-record a chapter because they did n't like the speaker , would [MASK] then offer two versions ?	you
[MASK] take the Wikipedia approach : if you think it should be better , please help it be so .	We
[MASK] 'll note we offer a couple of versions of some books .	You
Indeed our weekly poetry [MASK] celebrates this diversity of voice : each week a new short poem is chosen and as many readers as wish to record a version , so you get 20 + versions of the same poem , a very interesting audio experience .	project
[MASK] mentioned Larry Lessig 's Free Culture , but it also includes some out of print titles by publishers who are open to the concept , such as O'Reilly .	You
Do [MASK] want to limit the scope of LibriVox strictly to old public domain works , or do you have plans to include recent works under reasonably permissive licenses as well ?	you
[MASK] are only doing public domain works , for a number of reasons , partly to keep simplicity in our copyright situation -- public domain means it s as simple as can be .	We
[MASK] makes things more complex .	CC
[MASK] find it makes things clear and easy to say : published works , public domain , and leave it at that .	we
As far as I can tell , [MASK] features " free as in beer " content  material which you can download , but which is n't under a free content license .	podiobooks.com
Instead of " public domain " , would n't " free [MASK] " work just as well , using something like the Free Content Definition to limit the scope ?	content
[MASK] needs more discussion obviously : we chose public domain because the texts we use are public domain and we did n't want to add new restrictions , especially not non-commercial , since already our recordings are being used for a number of commercialish projects ( I ca n't recall any specific project names , but some pay - education sites use LV stuff ) .	This
[MASK] 's good and well and fine with us .	That
[MASK] do n't want to have to give anyone permission to use our recordings , we want anyone to use them for whatever they want .	We
Also , for the thing to work [MASK] need to have many dedicated volunteers willing to do the management ( onerous ) and many willing to do the reading .	you
While Pride and Prejudice will attract many readers , [MASK] do n't know about O'Reilly 's latest tome on XML ... though I might be wrong .	I
On Saturday , [MASK] interviewed Tina McKenzie , a former member of the Australia women 's national wheelchair basketball team , known as the Gliders .	Wikinews
[MASK] , a silver and bronze Paralympic medalist in wheelchair basketball , retired from the game after the 2012 Summer Paralympics in London .	McKenzie
[MASK] caught up with her in a cafe in the leafy Melbourne suburb of Preston .	Wikinews
[ The Spitfire [MASK] in Canada ] was a really good tournament actually .	Tournament

[MASK] plays in that one ?	Who
[MASK] 's quite a large Canadian tournament , and so we went as the Gliders team .	It
So [MASK] were trying to get as many international games as possible .	we
Cause [MASK] 's one of our problems really , to compete .	that
And so [MASK] can compete against each other all the time within Australia but we really need to be able to ...	we
[MASK] 's not the same .	It
No , [MASK] 's really not , so it 's really important to be able to get as a many international trips throughout the year to continue our improvement .	it
But yes , [MASK] was good .	Spitfire
[MASK] took quite a few new girls over there back then in 2005 , leading into the World Cup in the Netherlands .	We
Was [MASK] the one where you were the captain of the team , in 2005 ?	that
Or was [MASK] a later one ?	that
No , [MASK] captained in 2010 .	I
And then [MASK] had a bit of some time off in 2011 .	I
The [MASK] have never won the World Championship .	Gliders
[MASK] always seem to have just a little bit of a chill out at the World Cup .	We
[MASK] do n't know why .	I
[MASK] 's really strange occurrence , over the years .	It
2002 World Cup , [MASK] won bronze .	we
Then in 2006 [MASK] ended up fourth .	we
[MASK] was one of the worst World Cups we 've played actually .	It
And then in 2010 we just ... [MASK] do n't know what happened .	I
[MASK] just did n't play as well as we thought we would .	We
But [MASK] know what ?	you
So [MASK] can come back home and revisit what you need to do and , you know , where the team 's at .	you
Unfortunately , [MASK] are talking about moving it so it will be on the year before the Paralympics .	they
Well , [MASK] would be sad .	that
[MASK] have received a good deal of attention recently .	You
Even though I 'm not Michael Jackson or somebody , when people come up to me and introduce themselves and say , ' Hey Frank , my name is John , ' [MASK] say , ' Hey John , my name is Frank ' and they laugh .	I
[MASK] 's a funny phenomenon .	It
[MASK] goes through your head when that happens ?	What
[MASK] understand it .	I
[MASK] 've gone to readings and concerts .	I
[MASK] look at it as human interaction .	I
Over the years [MASK] have performed in 32 countries and 40 states .	I
[MASK] 've been doing this professionally since I was in my twenties , and before that since I was sixteen doing little tidbit poetry readings in coffeehouses .	I
The [MASK] I started in 1993 , Spoken Motion , received a lot of recognition as a spoken word band born out of the New York spoken word scene .	band
[MASK] worked with some great musicians and performed around the world .	I
[MASK] remember signing my first autograph to a kid when I was 25 years old .	I
As time went on , [MASK] came out with books and CDs , and I became used to that kind of thing .	I
When [MASK] comes up and says , ' Frank , thank you , your work is great . "	someone
[MASK] have a long career in poetry , but as of late the attention you have garnered is for the Mets - inspired work .	You
How do [MASK] feel about having a lot of your work overshadowed by the Mets work ?	you
[MASK] 's ironic .	It
[MASK] Whitman , the first great American poet , wrote about the Civil War .	Walt
[MASK] went looking for his brother , George Whitman , after he a telegram telling him his brother was injured in the South .	He
Then [MASK] started to see the real horrors of war .	he
[MASK] was able to tap into the human condition and the situation at that time .	He
Eventually when he found his brother [MASK] had resolution .	he
[MASK] experienced that kind of adversity during 9/11 being a civilian volunteer .	I
[MASK] loaded ferry boats in Jersey City across the river to deliver goods to Ground Zero .	I
[MASK] turned to Whitman to find some understanding of what is happening in the world right now .	I
When I wrote my 9/11 - related poems , [MASK] was true adversity .	that
[MASK] realize baseball is just a game .	I
Can [MASK] recite a stanza that expresses how you feel right now ?	you
[MASK] was a piece that the Times only quoted one stanza , but it 's about preparation for a battle , and being prepared to either rise to the occasion , or go down :	This
Do [MASK] know what it 's like to be chased by the Ghost of Failure while staring through Victory 's door ?	you
Of course you do , [MASK] 're a Mets fan caught in a do - or - die moment in late September at Shea	you
[MASK] 've kept it up this long	you
[MASK] 're a Mets fan in late September and you ll fight til the glorious end	You
Have [MASK] had interaction with " new readers ' through your Mets work ?	you
This one [MASK] who I never met took a picture of me and sent it to me in an e-mail .	person
The [MASK] said , ' Frank , I have never bothered you during the game , but I just wanted to say thank you for your work and thank you for making some sense of the successes and failures and I wish you much success with your work . '	e-mail
Last year in my section at the stadium [MASK] had a banner that read We Know ' .	I
[MASK] 's all it said .	That
Then earlier this year these [MASK] started to come out that said , " Poet says We Know " .	shirts
[MASK] was amazing .	It
[MASK] did n't use the banner this year , though , because we did n't know .	We
The [MASK] was n't so far ahead that we knew .	team
Last year [MASK] just knew we were going to the playoffs ; we knew we were going post-season .	we
This year [MASK] were n't sure .	we
[MASK] were walking on eggshells .	We
Last year [MASK] came up to me during one of the games late in the season ; she was so happy we were going to the post season .	she
By that point [MASK] had clinched it .	we
[MASK] handed me a shirt she bought at the stadium and she gave me a big hug .	She
With tears in her eyes [MASK] said , " Thank you , Mets Poet , thank you . "	she
[MASK] 's cool ... it 's like another family .	It
[MASK] like that must make you realize you have touched people who are n't normally touched by poetry .	Moments
[MASK] 's opened up a new fan base , so to speak .	It
For the last year [MASK] has broadcast footage of me with my poems , so quite a few fans known about the " Mets Poet ' .	SNY
[MASK] have never called myself that , by the way .	I
The [MASK] of my jersey says " The Poet ' because growing up that was my nickname .	back
My [MASK] was a runner and they used to call him The Birdman -- Birdie -- and they called me The Poet .	brother
[MASK] was a natural thing , but I never coined myself as ' The Mets Poet . '	It
This exclusive [MASK] features first - hand journalism by a Wikinews reporter .	interview
How do [MASK] decide on the stories ?	you
[MASK] do everything backwards here .	We
[MASK] start with the headline and then flesh out the story , as opposed to The New York Times , which writes the issue and then has a headline editor to make it snappy .	We
[MASK] start with a joke .	We
[MASK] read about six hundred to eight hundred headline ideas on a Monday coming from our staff and a small group of writers outside  a contributing core .	We
[MASK] whittle that down on a Monday to about a hundred , come in Tuesday and pick an issue and brainstorm with the whole editorial staff ; all fifteen of us .	We
Then [MASK] assign a headline to a specific writer to execute .	we
[MASK] go through a number of drafts and then have the editors pick it up and assign the photojournalism aspect of it to our graphic design team , who adds the visual aspect to it .	We
The [MASK] punch it up over the last couple of days and then it goes out over the Internet and into the print edition .	editors
So [MASK] do nt have writers coming up with a story and headline , but you will instead have a team of writers choosing the best headlines and then assign it to a particular writer who was not necessarily involved ?	you
[MASK] will occasionally write their own headlines , but we come up with a list of 15 or 20 headline ideas , what we think will make a good story and then we assign it based upon what people s writing strengths are .	Writers
[MASK] have some people who are great at politics ; some people we give all the war stuff to ; someone who is in charge of the Britney Spears story of the week  the entertainment stories .	We
[MASK] are a little less reactionary .	We
[MASK] tend to target the zeitgeist more than anything .	We
[MASK] ll hit the mainstream media s portrayal of the entertainment world as much as we ll hit characters in the entertainment world .	We
[MASK] ll attack People Magazine s coverage of Britney as much as Britney .	We
In an interview with Terry Gross , [MASK] Colbert said of his time at Second City that they had decided on not doing political humor and , in particular , hackneyed political humor such as Ted Kennedy drinking jokes .	Stephen
[MASK] felt it was overdone , mean - spirited and not funny .	They
Do your [MASK] have similar rules of thumb ?	writers
[MASK] do nt have any rules or known lines we wo nt cross .	We
[MASK] have an understanding based upon having the same writers in the back room for years , and those writers training the new writers as they come in .	We
If it makes the room laugh , [MASK] probably ends up in the paper .	it
One example is [MASK] ran an article a couple of years back that was , " No Jennifer Lopez News Today " .	we
[MASK] was our reaction to all of the J - Lo stuff .	That
[MASK] were nt going to touch on her dress , or who she was dating .	We
[MASK] think it s important we have an original take on those things .	I
[MASK] think it s similar to what Colbert said to Terry Gross .	I
[MASK] do nt want to just traffic in the same 24 hour news cycle .	We
The [MASK] has a different creative process where we are not trying to hit everything in the 24 hours and on the same notes .	Onion
[MASK] want an original take .	We
If we choose to do something on J - Lo , [MASK] s going to be something like that , something less obvious .	it
When you are going through the headlines , is [MASK] just you guys sitting around trying to crack each other up ?	it
[MASK] s the least amount of fun possible .	It
Nah , [MASK] m kidding .	I
[MASK] s actually more businesslike than you d imagine .	It
It s very much like [MASK] are trying to make the room laugh , but the room has been a sort of captive audience for many many years now , so it takes a lot to make the room laugh .	you
The best [MASK] I ve heard is when Rob Siegel , former editor - in - chief , likened it to wine tasting .	analogy
[MASK] s this quiet experience where you are trying to soak in what the joke is , have we done anything like this , is it a unique take , what are other people doing .	It
It s sort of like , " Hmmm ... [MASK] s hilarious . That s really really funny " rather than people falling off their chairs .	that
[MASK] s more subdued than I think what most people would expect .	It
[MASK] s more analytical and clinical ?	It
Yeah , what you see on Studio 60 and 30 Rock , [MASK] are scripted writers rooms .	those
[MASK] is funny there .	Everything
If someone is continually telling unfunny jokes , do [MASK] eventually fire them ?	you
[MASK] s why we are on the 10th floor to make sure they die when they get kicked out .	That
[MASK] can be a real mess on Broadway .	It
By the time you get to be a writer for The Onion , though , the odds are [MASK] are going to succeed because we make it pretty challenging .	you
[MASK] go through quite a bit .	You
[MASK] will already have demonstrated a pretty long successful record of writing stuff for us before you will be in that room on a daily basis .	You
" The [MASK] is only peace . The problem is how long will it take and how many victims will it call for . "	future
Mr. President , as a Nobel Peace Prize recipient and as one of the fathers of the modern peace process in Israel , do [MASK] still think that there is a future to the peace process ?	you
The [MASK] is only peace .	future
The problem is how long will [MASK] take and how many victims will it call for .	it
Why do [MASK] say peace ?	I
Because when you look historically , at the development of humanity , most of our lives [MASK] are living on the land .	we
The reason for it is because [MASK] were fighting for our land , either defending it or extending it , because that was the main source .	people
The land , the natural resources , the markets , all [MASK] go together .	these
[MASK] can not conquer science .	Armies
[MASK] can not check what a scientist has in his mind , they can see what he has in his pocket but not what he has in his mind so it s uncontrolled ; it means that borders are nt important and distances are nt important .	Customs
How do [MASK] approach the difficult challenge of talking to the Palestinians when , in the end , they do nt want Israel to exist .	you
How do [MASK] come to an understanding to make peace possible ?	you
Well , [MASK] is the problem ?	what
[MASK] mean , is the problem national , say between Jews and Arabs ; or is it a matter of generations between an old age and a new age ?	I
You see , the [MASK] are protesting against modernity .	terrorists
[MASK] think that modernity may endanger their tradition .	They
[MASK] are simply afraid and hate modernity .	They
[MASK] consider modernity as their enemy , but then they have two problems .	They
First of all , can [MASK] exist on tradition ?	they
[MASK] can not .	They
Sooner or later [MASK] will have to enter the new age .	they
All the talks about nationalities , etcetera , well , the new [MASK] has very little patience for history .	age
[MASK] is becoming more and more irrelevant .	History
How do [MASK] feel about that ?	you
Well , [MASK] distinguish between two histories , the spiritual and the material .	I
The [MASK] of values is okay because wisdom is ageless ; it does nt grow old , like material .	history
But [MASK] are totally unimportant for 2 reasons .	events
First , the [MASK] is unimportant .	event
Why should [MASK] bother my children with all this nonsense ?	I
What sort of a nose did [MASK] have ?	Cleopatra
God , [MASK] do nt know !	I
[MASK] can invite people to war over noses , but nobody will go to fight for noses any more .	You
Why should [MASK] bother my child with memory when he can buy a computer that will remember everything you asked him to remember ?	I
Although a [MASK] can have 	computer
Look , the new [MASK] is unprecedented .	age
When something is unprecedented , [MASK] means it does nt have a past , does nt have a history .	it
And [MASK] dwells in the past , does nt understand the future because the past is full of prejudices , of commitments .	whoever
[MASK] arrests us .	It
And then [MASK] say you wo nt commit a mistake , so you ll commit new mistakes .	you
[MASK] does nt matter .	It
`` [MASK] say brains is the greater producer of wealth , not oil .	I
[MASK] s limitless , and you ll see that the GNP of Israel is very close to the Saudis  .	It
So [MASK] are 3 times larger than us and they have all the oil in the world .	they
[MASK] have brains . "	We
 Peres , on whether the Arab states ' oil [MASK] will eclipse Israel 's prominence in the region .	wealth
So [MASK] will make new mistakes .	they
[MASK] is inevitable as long as there are human beings .	Mistake
But [MASK] can not repeat mistakes because the world is not built on repetition ; it s built on mutation .	you
Do nt [MASK] think Darfur is repetition ?	you
[MASK] think Darfur is , again , the last , or among the last battles between old and new .	I
What are [MASK] fighting for ?	they
What are [MASK] killing killing killing over ?	they
[MASK] do nt carry futures .	They
[MASK] s not a mistake .	It
[MASK] belongs to a past .	It
[MASK] does nt have a moment .	It
[MASK] am sure that the reasons for war are over , even though still there are wars which are an inertia from the past , a continuation that does nt make sense .	I
[MASK] m answering your question .	I
[MASK] s not a geographic endeavor , it is an intellectual endeavor .	It
[MASK] say you can be Muslim and modern .	They
[MASK] interviews Israeli mathematician and writer Aner Shalev	Wikinews
[MASK] Shalev is an Israeli mathematician and writer born in 1958 in Kibbutz Kinneret , Tiberias .	Aner
Currently [MASK] is a Professor at Hebrew University of Jerusalem 's Einstein Institute of Mathematics .	Shalev
At the moment [MASK] is in Levico Terme , Trento , Italy for a conference .	Shalev
What are [MASK] going to talk about here in Levico ?	you
[MASK] called it Character , walks and words .	I
It 's very beautiful [MASK] think .	I
And then when you do it in an asymptotic way is like [MASK] do n't look at the small details .	you
[MASK] 's like from the sky .	It
[MASK] look at the general patterns .	You
So [MASK] will mainly talk about how to use a representation theory to solve all kind of problems and conjectures in asymptotic groups theory .	I
Why did [MASK] choose to study mathematics ?	you
First of all because [MASK] was beautiful .	it
When I was ten my [MASK] already showed me some stuff in mathematics and the beauty and the imagination was quite apparent .	father
[MASK] also like the freedom in mathematics .	I
If you study physics or chemistry then [MASK] should describe the real world .	you
But in mathematics [MASK] can build your own structures .	you
[MASK] can walk in worlds created by the imagination of people .	You
[MASK] 's almost like God to some extent .	It
You can create worlds , [MASK] can study them .	you
[MASK] think it 's a combination of the beauty , of the imagination , of the freedom .	I
Many [MASK] , and many students , dislike math .	people
Why do [MASK] think it is so ?	you
First of all [MASK] think maybe they have bad teachers , which is a problem .	I
[MASK] have to have very good teachers in mathematics if you really want to enjoy and to succeed in it .	You
Probably some [MASK] mainly think about the scientific part of it  you have to be accurate - and they see less these elements of the freedom , and the imagination , and creation .	people
Maybe [MASK] do n't like the precise nature of mathematics .	they
Also when I talk mathematics [MASK] notice the language is very important in mathematics and I actually notice that many times people fail in mathematics because they do n't know how to write a composition .	I
[MASK] have ideas but they can not formulate them in the right way .	They
Actually [MASK] find many connections between mathematics and literature because almost all the thing I told about mathematics are also seen in literature and in writing because when you write you can describe the real world , but you can also create worlds of fiction .	I
So [MASK] have imagination , you have total freedom , you can invent characters , you can invent all kind of development and surprises and this kind of end of story or another .	you
Also the [MASK] is important in writing and in literature .	language
So in a way [MASK] often do n't know how to combine the two fields .	people
[MASK] could look like almost the opposite : literature is kind of arts and mathematics is science but they also see a lot in common and there where mathematician who were writers .	It
For example the most [MASK] is Lewis Carrol , author of Alice in Wonderland .	famous
[MASK] 're not only a mathematician .	You
[MASK] also wrote two collections of short stories and a novel .	You
Why did [MASK] begin to write ?	you
When I was quite young [MASK] was interested in psychoanalysis and in dreams .	I
[MASK] was trying to interpret my dreams .	I
[MASK] started to write down my dreams .	I
And then [MASK] noticed that I cheat a little bit when I write them down .	I
Sometimes I make them more pretty then [MASK] were actually .	they
So instead of documenting the dreams [MASK] gradually became also like adding creational elements , and I think that somehow through writing my dreams I gradually came to writing , also poems , but mainly stories .	it
In the legato part the [MASK] are very long and without breaks almost like stream of consciousness .	sentences
In the staccato part [MASK] 's like a music : a lot of break , very very short sentences .	it
[MASK] was a bit experimenting connections between the language and the music and the psychology of people .	It
In the second book [MASK] made another experiment .	I
[MASK] 's a book of opening , Overtures I called it , and there is no end to the stories .	It
In the novel Dark Matters [MASK] think what interested me in the structure was two thing : simple narrative and email .	I
[MASK] keeps changing between narrative and email .	It
Another [MASK] was two different time scapes : one goes very slow and one goes very fast and they almost kind of meet in the end .	thing
[MASK] 's a little bit like Achilles and the turtle .	It
... love [MASK] and romance and surprises and tragedies and all this but also this structure interested me a lot .	story
Why did [MASK] choose this particular structure ?	you
When I tell stories [MASK] do n't like that everything will be clear from the beginning .	I
[MASK] like that something will be a bit of secret , or even unreliable narrator : someone tells something and first you trust him but then you read more and you become thrilled by everything .	I
I think by using emails on the one hand which are more the voice of the woman Eva and narrative which is more the perspective of the man Adam , [MASK] kind of confront them , their different perspective and then kind somehow you can see the distortions in the way the story is told .	I
[MASK] think that in this kind of structure there is a very gradual clarification of the relationship and the forth going on .	I
[MASK] is a NASA space capsule that collected samples from comet 81P/Wild ( also known as " Wild 2 ) in deep space and landed back on Earth on January 15 , 2006 .	Stardust
Unlike distributed computing projects like SETI @ home , [MASK] @ home relies entirely on human intelligence .	Stardust
[MASK] Westphal is the director of Stardust @ home .	Andrew
[MASK] interviewed him for May 's Interview of the Month ( IOTM ) on May 18 , 2006 .	Wikinews
[MASK] may not know exactly what Stardust or Stardust @ home is .	Some
Can [MASK] explain more about it for us ?	you
[MASK] is a NASA Discovery mission that was launched in 1999 .	Stardust
[MASK] is really two missions in one .	It
[MASK] is the first US " sample return " mission since Apollo , and the first ever from beyond the moon .	This
[MASK] gives a little context .	This
By " sample return " of course [MASK] mean a mission that brings back extraterrestrial material .	I
[MASK] should have said above that this is the first " solid " sample return mission 	I
[MASK] brought back a sample from the Sun almost two years ago , but Stardust is also bringing back the first solid samples from the local interstellar medium 	Genesis
basically [MASK] is a sample of the Galaxy .	this
[MASK] is absolutely unprecedented , and we 're obviously incredibly excited .	This
[MASK] should mention parenthetically that there is a fantastic launch video  taken from the POV of the rocket on the JPL Stardust website  highly recommended  best I 've ever seen  all the way from the launch pad , too .	I
Is the [MASK] available to the public ?	video
OK , [MASK] digress .	I
[MASK] is a big challenge because they are very small ( order of micron in size ) and are somewhere ( we do n't know where ) on a HUGE collector  at least on the scale of the particle size  about a tenth of a square meter .	This
[MASK] 're right now using an automated microscope that we developed several years ago for nuclear astrophysics work to scan the collector in the Cosmic Dust Lab in Building 31 at Johnson Space Center .	We
[MASK] is the ARES group that handles returned samples ( Moon Rocks , Genesis chips , Meteorites , and Interplanetary Dust Particles collected by U2 in the stratosphere ) .	This
The [MASK] collects stacks of digital images of the aerogel collectors in the array .	microscope
[MASK] @ home is a highly distributed project using a " Virtual Microscope " that is written in html and javascript and runs on most browsers  no downloads are required .	Stardust
Using the Virtual Microscope [MASK] can search over the collector for the tracks of the interstellar dust particles .	volunteers
How many samples do [MASK] anticipate being found during the course of the project ?	you
The short answer is that [MASK] do n't know .	we
The long [MASK] is a bit more complicated .	answer
The Galileo and Ulysses [MASK] carried dust detectors onboard that Eberhard Gruen and his colleagues used to first detect and them measure the flux of interstellar dust particles streaming into the solar system .	spacecraft
( [MASK] is a kind of " wind " of interstellar dust , caused by the fact that our solar system is moving with respect to the local interstellar medium . )	This
[MASK] Landgraf has estimated the number of interstellar dust particles that should have been captured by Stardust during two periods of the " cruise " phase of the interplanetary orbit in which the spacecraft was moving with this wind .	Markus
[MASK] estimated that there should be around 45 particles , but this number is very uncertain  I would n't be surprised if it is quite different from that .	He
[MASK] was the long answer !	That
One thing that I should say ... is that like all research , the [MASK] of what we are doing is highly uncertain .	outcome
[MASK] expect that the particles will be of order a micron in size .	We
When people are searching using the virtual microscope , [MASK] will be looking not for the particles , but for the tracks that the particles make , which are much larger  several microns in diameter .	they
Just yesterday [MASK] switched over to a new site which has a demo of the VM ( virtual microscope ) I invite you to check it out .	we
The [MASK] in the demo are from submicron carbonyl iron particles that were shot into aerogel using a particle accelerator modified to accelerate dust particles to very high speeds , to simulate the interstellar dust impacts that we 're looking for .	tracks
And [MASK] 's on the main Stardust @ home website [ see below ] ?	that
The [MASK] later personally took action to allow the team into the country .	President

The [MASK] whose three robots collectively earned the most points won that match .	group

On Friday , [MASK] rescued over 700 asylum seekers whose boat sank , and the Indonesian Navy reportedly saved 200 more after they were found swimming along the coast of Aceh , Indonesia .	fishermen
Major [MASK] Fuad Basya , spokesman for the Indonesian military , said fisherman first noticed the people and a warship was deployed to retrieve them .	general
The rescued [MASK] included Bangladeshis and Rohingya , a stateless minority of Muslims from Myanmar .	members
[MASK] is mainly Buddhist and the United Nations rates the Rohingya among the world 's most persecuted groups .	Myanmar
According to ABC News , [MASK] also believes the asylum seekers found in the water may have left the boat on purpose to be rescued to avoid being sent away from Indonesia waters .	Basya
[MASK] and Indonesia have maintained a policy of turning away boats of migrants which , according to AFP , the Untied Nations and United States have both criticised .	Malaysia
Discussing his concern in a public statement , Malaysia 's Prime [MASK] , Najib Razak said , " We are in contact with all relevant parties , with whom we share the desire to find a solution to this crisis " .	Minister
[MASK] has recently cracked down on human trafficking , which has affected the routes by which people - smugglers transport migrants .	Thailand
The US State [MASK] said John Kerry , the Secretary of State , contacted Thailand 's foreign minister over temporary housing for the Rohingya out at sea .	Department
[MASK] Rathke , the State Department Spokesperson , said , " We urge the governments of the region to work together quickly , first and foremost , to save the lives of migrants now at sea who are in need of an immediate rescue effort " .	Jeff
[MASK] also asked the governments of South East Asia not to turn away boats of people seeking asylum .	Rathke
[MASK] suggest 8000 migrants may be currently at sea in the region .	Estimates
Texas [MASK] Ahmed Mohamed inspires social movement	student
[MASK] of police response to a boy 's digital clock in Texas last week has inspired a global social movement in support of the youth .	News
After news of the police response was reported , [MASK] received support online ranging from US President Barack Obama to Facebook creator Mark Zuckerberg .	Mohamed
Yesterday [MASK] received VIP attention at Google headquarters in California at the Google Science Fair  and tomorrow he plans to meet international dignitaries at the United Nations headquarters in New York .	Mohamed
[MASK] brought the digital clock he made to school on September 14 , and a teacher mistakenly thought it resembled a bomb .	Mohamed
[MASK] arrested and questioned the student .	Police
The Deseret [MASK] observed that the hashtag on Twitter , #IStandWithAhmed , had become an international phenomenon .	News
The Straits [MASK] noted what began as individual messages to Mohamed had grown into a " support movement " .	Times
American academic and professor [MASK] Lamont Hill commented ,	Marc
The Twitter [MASK] led to outreach from Google and Mohamed was invited to their Google Science Fair .	attention
[MASK] was a VIP guest at the Google Science Fair this weekend , and was able to meet finalists at the event held at Google 's headquarters located in Mountain View , California .	Mohamed
[MASK] of Google , Sergey Brin , personally met with Mohamed during his visit to Google .	Co-founder
On Wednesday , [MASK] and his father are to travel to the United Nations .	Mohamed
His [MASK] Mohamed El - Hassan Mohamed said he was taking his entire family to the U.N. headquarters in New York , because international dignitaries wanted to meet with his son and express their support .	father
Psychology [MASK] at University of Texas Arlington Amneh Jafari heard of the incident and wanted to issue her support to Mohamed .	major
[MASK] chose the hastag #IStandWithAhmed and posted to Twitter .	She
[MASK] said she felt Mohamed had been subject to Islamophobia and her hashtag created greater awareness about this issue .	Jafari
The [MASK] took on a life of its own , and was used in messages on Twitter over one million times by Thursday night .	hashtag
[MASK] tweeted support of Ahmed Mohamed via its account International Space Station	NASA
US [MASK] Barack Obama tweeted using his @POTUS account :	President
[MASK] should inspire more kids like you to like science .	We
[MASK] 's what makes America great . "	It
[MASK] gave Mohamed the option to come to their company for an internship .	Twitter
Facebook [MASK] Mark Zuckerberg tweeted to Mohamed and said the boy was welcome to come and tour the company .	co-founder
Executive director of the Dallas chapter of the Council on American - Islamic Relations [MASK] Salem said Mohamed wishes to use his newfound fame and attention to spotlight social causes including the treatment of Muslims in the United States .	Alia

[MASK] also said she believed the social movement in reaction to Mohamed helped improve Muslim / non-Muslim .	Memon

Civil Defense Authority [MASK] General Suleiman al - Amr , in remarks to al - Ikhbariya television , said " All those who were wounded and the dead have been taken to hospital . There are no casualties left at the location . "	director
[MASK] released of the scene showed numerous bloodied bodies and various scattered debris .	Photos
The [MASK] occurred at a time when the mosque was relatively uncrowded .	accident
" Had it happened an hour later it would have been much worse , " [MASK] Al - Maeena , editor at large at the Saudi Gazette , said .	Khaled
" Had it happened five hours earlier or four hours earlier , [MASK] think the death toll would have been more than a thousand . "	I
The crane [MASK] comes just ten days before the beginning of the Hajj , the annual pilgrimage to Mecca , Islam 's holiest site .	accident
As undergoing a pilgrimage to Mecca is a mandatory religious duty for all Muslims who physically and financially can , [MASK] of pilgrims arrive in Mecca each year for the Hajj .	millions

[MASK] of the Sea Org live a strict lifestyle  with little income , small diet provided and significant time invested in work per day .	Members
