Many [MASK] who migrated to Texas at the invitation of the Mexican government did not completely shed their identity or loyalty to the United States .	Americans
[MASK] brought American traditions and expectations with them ( including , for many , the right to own slaves ) .	They
For instance , the [MASK] of these new settlers were Protestant , and though they were not required to attend the Catholic mass , Mexico 's prohibition on the public practice of other religions upset them and they routinely ignored it .	majority
Accustomed to representative democracy , jury trials , and the defendant s right to appear before a judge , the Anglo - American [MASK] in Texas also disliked the Mexican legal system , which provided for an initial hearing by an alcalde , an administrator who often combined the duties of mayor , judge , and law enforcement officer .	settlers
The [MASK] sent a written record of the proceeding to a judge in Saltillo , the state capital , who decided the outcome .	alcalde
[MASK] also resented that at most two Texas representatives were allowed in the state legislature .	Settlers
Their greatest [MASK] of discontent , though , was the Mexican government 's 1829 abolition of slavery .	source
Most American [MASK] were from southern states , and many had brought slaves with them .	settlers
[MASK] tried to accommodate them by maintaining the fiction that the slaves were indentured servants .	Mexico
But American [MASK] in Texas distrusted the Mexican government and wanted Texas to be a new U.S. slave state .	slaveholders
The [MASK] of most for Roman Catholicism ( the prevailing religion of Mexico ) and a widely held belief in American racial superiority led them generally to regard Mexicans as dishonest , ignorant , and backward .	dislike
This 1833 [MASK] shows the extent of land grants made by Mexico to American settlers in Texas .	map
Nearly [MASK] are in the eastern portion of the state , one factor that led to war with Mexico in 1846 .	all
[MASK] in their own superiority inspired some Texans to try to undermine the power of the Mexican government .	Belief
When empresario Haden Edwards attempted to evict people who had settled his land grant before he gained title to it , the Mexican [MASK] nullified its agreement with him .	government
Outraged , [MASK] and a small party of men took prisoner the alcalde of Nacogdoches .	Edwards
The Mexican [MASK] marched to the town , and Edwards and his troops then declared the formation of the Republic of Fredonia between the Sabine and Rio Grande Rivers .	army
To demonstrate loyalty to their adopted country , a [MASK] led by Stephen Austin hastened to Nacogdoches to support the Mexican army .	force
Edwards s [MASK] collapsed , and the revolutionaries fled Texas .	revolt
The growing [MASK] of American settlers in Texas , their reluctance to abide by Mexican law , and their desire for independence caused the Mexican government to grow wary .	presence
In 1830 , [MASK] forbade future U.S. immigration and increased its military presence in Texas .	it
[MASK] continued to stream illegally across the long border ; by 1835 , after immigration resumed , there were twenty thousand Anglo - Americans in Texas .	Settlers
Fifty - five [MASK] from the Anglo - American settlements gathered in 1831 to demand the suspension of customs duties , the resumption of immigration from the United States , better protection from Indian tribes , the granting of promised land titles , and the creation of an independent state of Texas separate from Coahuila .	delegates
Ordered to disband , the [MASK] reconvened in early April 1833 to write a constitution for an independent Texas .	delegates
Surprisingly , [MASK] Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna , Mexico s new president , agreed to all demands , except the call for statehood .	General
[MASK] y Texas made provisions for jury trials , increased Texas s representation in the state legislature , and removed restrictions on commerce .	Coahuila
This [MASK] of General Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna depicts the Mexican president and general in full military regalia .	portrait
In January 1835 , reneging on earlier promises , [MASK] dispatched troops to the town of Anahuac to collect customs duties .	he
[MASK] and soldier William B. Travis and a small force marched on Anahuac in June , and the fort surrendered .	Lawyer
On October 2 , Anglo - American [MASK] met Mexican troops at the town of Gonzales ; the Mexican troops fled and the Americans moved on to take San Antonio .	forces
Now more cautious , [MASK] to the Consultation of 1835 at San Felipe de Austin voted against declaring independence , instead drafting a statement , which became known as the Declaration of Causes , promising continued loyalty if Mexico returned to a constitutional form of government .	delegates
[MASK] selected Henry Smith , leader of the Independence Party , as governor of Texas and placed Sam Houston , a former soldier who had been a congressman and governor of Tennessee , in charge of its small military force .	They
The Consultation [MASK] met again in March 1836 .	delegates
[MASK] declared their independence from Mexico and drafted a constitution calling for an American - style judicial system and an elected president and legislature .	They
Significantly , [MASK] also established that slavery would not be prohibited in Texas .	they
Many wealthy [MASK] supported the push for independence , hoping for liberal governmental reforms and economic benefits .	Tejanos
[MASK] had no intention of losing its northern province .	Mexico
[MASK] Anna and his army of four thousand had besieged San Antonio in February 1836 .	Santa
Hopelessly outnumbered , its two hundred [MASK] , under Travis , fought fiercely from their refuge in an old mission known as the Alamo .	defenders
Terrified , [MASK] fled .	they
The [MASK] of the Alamo , painted by Theodore Gentilz fewer than ten years after this pivotal moment in the Texas Revolution , depicts the 1836 assault on the Alamo complex .	Fall
A [MASK] comes to class one day , and the instructor says ,  I ve decided that you re all a bunch of failures and I m flunking the entire class . 	student
The [MASK] announces ,  I ve decided that you re all a bunch of failures and I m flunking the entire class . 	instructor
Then , as the class erupts in protest , the [MASK] calmly blinks one eye , leaving the other eye open .	instructor
Would [MASK] take this woman seriously ?	you
[MASK] just happened there ?	What
[MASK] blink to keep eyes hydrated and clear of debris .	Humans
On average , [MASK] blink 15 to 20 times every minute .	humans
Without realizing it , [MASK] are necessarily blinking throughout every conversation , every social interaction , every activity during the day .	people
The [MASK] we talk to and interact with are also blinking constantly , so often that everyone is accustomed to ignoring it .	people
But if someone deliberately blinks one eye , leaving the other one open , [MASK] s a completely different matter .	that
In American culture ( and many others ) , a [MASK] often indicates that someone is joking around and that whatever they ve just said or done should not be taken seriously .	wink
Of course , a [MASK] can mean different things in different societies .	wink
Moreover , a [MASK] can mean different things in the same society .	wink
If someone on a date takes their companion s hand and gives a cute little wink , the [MASK] may have reason to hope the winker is not just joking around .	person
American cultural [MASK] Clifford Geertz ( 1973 ) used the example of winking to illustrate two important aspects of culture .	anthropologist
Innate human [MASK]  that is , behaviors that people are born with  are biological , not cultural .	behaviors
Acquired human [MASK]  that is , behaviors that people are taught  are cultural .	behaviors
[MASK] means that cultural behaviors are not genetically inherited from generation to generation but must be passed down from older members of a society to younger members .	This
Some [MASK] of enculturation are deliberate and systematic , such as learning the rules of written punctuation in a language .	aspects
At some point in an English speaker s childhood , [MASK] explicitly told them the difference between a question mark and an exclamation point .	someone
Most likely , [MASK] learned this distinction in school , a fundamental institution of enculturation in many societies .	they
Religious [MASK] are another common force of enculturation , providing explicit instruction in cultural rules of morality and social interaction .	institutions
Extracurricular [MASK] such as sports , dance , and music lessons also teach children cultural rules and norms .	activities
By virtue of growing up in a culture , [MASK] learn what certain actions and objects mean , how their society operates , and what the rules are for appropriate behavior .	children
Going back to the cultural notion of home , did [MASK] ever explain to you why your childhood home was structured in a certain way ?	anyone
Did [MASK] ever point out the cultural assumptions about gender and family built into your house ?	anyone
Living in that house , [MASK] would have wordlessly absorbed a set of assumptions about family , gender , work , leisure , hospitality , and property .	you
And [MASK] of it would seem quite natural to you .	all
Perhaps when you were a child , [MASK] told you what a wink was and showed you how to accomplish one ; or perhaps you just witnessed a few winks , figured out what they meant from their contexts , and then learned how to accomplish one through trial and error .	someone
[MASK] pointed out that there are two important aspects to winking : the meaning and the action .	Geertz
As both are learned , [MASK] are cultural .	both
A relevant question to our concern might be , would this artistic [MASK] in the Chinese tradition be the same as beauty ?	excellence
If we browse Chinese classical writings on art criticism , a striking [MASK] manifests  there the category of mei or beauty does not have a dominant presence .	difference
Moreover , according to Xu Hong s ( c. 1580  1660 ) Xishan Qinkuang   ( c. 1640 ) , the most influential treatise on the aesthetics of guqin ( Chinese zither ) music , the [MASK] of li ( pretty , beautiful ) is merely the 10th of the 24 aesthetic categories , and the top six were harmony , tranquillity , clarity , profundity , antiquity , subtlety . [ 38 ]	category
Overall , [MASK] also finds that the comparison between the beautiful and the sublime  which defined the influential aesthetics of Edmund Burke ( 1729  1797 ) and Immanuel Kant , and consequently became an iconic discourse in Western aesthetics  is also missing in the Chinese history of aesthetics .	one
The Hegelian [MASK] of aesthetics as the philosophy of art that considers the issue of artistic beauty as its core concern is no more enchanting in our time .	definition
[MASK] would agree that the question  what makes an artwork beautiful  plays a minor role in contemporary aesthetics and philosophy of art , where the question has been updated to  what makes an artwork meaningful or valuable ? 	Many
Two [MASK] might contribute to this situation .	factors
Also , when the representationalism , the expression theories , formalism , neoformalism , aesthetic theories in defining art all fail to offer an account that is capable of coping with the dynamic scenes of the artworld , and when the anti-essentialist movement in philosophical aesthetics then paves a way to functionalism , institutionalism and various versions of historicism , the [MASK] of artistic beauty as such not only loses its limelight , but also is , to some extent , abandoned for its strong Hegelian colour .	question
Secondly , the [MASK] into  beauty  experienced a shift of focus from the emphasis on aesthetic properties of the objects to the subjective experience involved in aesthetic appreciation .	inquiry
[MASK] regards artistic beauty as a property of artworks which is independent of the subject , while non-realism holds that artistic beauty is not an independent property of artworks .	Realism
This [MASK] has a long historical preparation , contributed especially by the British empiricists such as Francis Hutcheson ( 1694  1746 ) and David Hume ( 1711  1776 ) .	shift
[MASK] thinks that beauty lies in both the object and the subject , and artistic beauty comes from the quality of  uniformity amidst variety  in the object and the involvement of an  internal sense  in the subject . [ 39 ]	Hutcheson
[MASK] argues that  beauty is no quality in things themselves ,  but a  sentiment  in  the mind that contemplates them  and  to seek the real beauty  is  fruitless .  [ 40 ]	Hume
In contemporary aesthetics , from the study of empathy to Freud s libido , to the evolutionary theory of beauty , to the focus on perception in aesthetic experience , more and more [MASK] seek to answer the question of what makes an artwork beautiful in light of human physiology and psychology .	philosophers
For instance , the evolutionary [MASK] regards artistic beauty as  fitness signal  that displays desirable personal qualities that strengthen reproductive advantage , and our pleasant feeling caused by something beautiful , like sexual pleasure , is engraved in our minds by the process of evolution , assisting us to make the  the most adaptive decisions for survival and reproduction .  [ 41 ]	theory
39.  The [MASK] which excite in us the Ideas of Beauty , seem to be those in which there is Uniformity amidst Variety  (  II , p. 28 ) .	Figures
 The internal [MASK] is , a passive Power of receiving Ideas of Beauty from all Objects in which there is Uniformity amidst Variety  (  VI , 67 ) .	Sense
40.  [MASK] is no quality in things themselves : it exists merely in the mind which contemplates them ; and each mind perceives a different beauty  every individual ought to acquiesce in his own sentiment , without pretending to regulate those of others .	Beauty
41. [MASK] Dutton ( 2010 ) provides such an account in his TED talk ,  A Darwinian Theory of Beauty . 	Denis
By the end of this section , [MASK] will be able to :	you
The [MASK] is endlessly perceiving , processing , planning , organizing , and remembering  it is always active .	brain
Yet , [MASK] do nt notice most of your brain s activity as you move throughout your daily routine .	you
[MASK] is only one facet of the complex processes involved in cognition .	This
Simply put , [MASK] is thinking , and it encompasses the processes associated with perception , knowledge , problem solving , judgment , language , and memory .	cognition
[MASK] who study cognition are searching for ways to understand how we integrate , organize , and utilize our conscious cognitive experiences without being aware of all of the unconscious work that our brains are doing ( for example , Kahneman , 2011 ) .	Scientists
Upon waking each morning , [MASK] begin thinking  contemplating the tasks that you must complete that day .	you
In what order should [MASK] run your errands ?	you
Should [MASK] go to the bank , the cleaners , or the grocery store first ?	you
Can [MASK] get these things done before you head to class or will they need to wait until school is done ?	you
These [MASK] are one example of cognition at work .	thoughts
Exceptionally complex , [MASK] is an essential feature of human consciousness , yet not all aspects of cognition are consciously experienced .	cognition
Cognitive [MASK] is the field of psychology dedicated to examining how people think .	psychology
[MASK] attempts to explain how and why we think the way we do by studying the interactions among human thinking , emotion , creativity , language , and problem solving , in addition to other cognitive processes .	It
Cognitive [MASK] strive to determine and measure different types of intelligence , why some people are better at problem solving than others , and how emotional intelligence affects success in the workplace , among countless other topics .	psychologists
[MASK] also sometimes focus on how we organize thoughts and information gathered from our environments into meaningful categories of thought , which will be discussed later .	They
The human nervous [MASK] is capable of handling endless streams of information .	system
The [MASK] serve as the interface between the mind and the external environment , receiving stimuli and translating it into nervous impulses that are transmitted to the brain .	senses
The [MASK] then processes this information and uses the relevant pieces to create thoughts , which can then be expressed through language or stored in memory for future use .	brain
To make this process more complex , the [MASK] does not gather information from external environments only .	brain
When thoughts are formed , the [MASK] also pulls information from emotions and memories ( Figure 7.2 ) .	brain
[MASK] and memory are powerful influences on both our thoughts and behaviors .	Emotion
In order to organize this staggering amount of information , the [MASK] has developed a file cabinet of sorts in the mind .	brain
[MASK] are categories or groupings of linguistic information , images , ideas , or memories , such as life experiences .	Concepts
[MASK] are , in many ways , big ideas that are generated by observing details , and categorizing and combining these details into cognitive structures .	Concepts
[MASK] use concepts to see the relationships among the different elements of your experiences and to keep the information in your mind organized and accessible .	You
When you study United States history , for example , [MASK] learn about more than just individual events that have happened in America s past .	you
[MASK] absorb a large quantity of information by listening to and participating in discussions , examining maps , and reading first - hand accounts of people s lives .	You
Your [MASK] analyzes these details and develops an overall understanding of American history .	brain
In the process , your [MASK] gathers details that inform and refine your understanding of related concepts like democracy , power , and freedom .	brain
[MASK] can be complex and abstract , like justice , or more concrete , like types of birds .	Concepts
In psychology , for example , Piaget s [MASK] of development are abstract concepts .	stages
Other [MASK] , like the characteristics of your ideal friend or your family s birthday traditions , are personal and individualized .	concepts
In this way , [MASK] touch every aspect of our lives , from our many daily routines to the guiding principles behind the way governments function .	concepts
Another [MASK] used by your brain to organize information is the identification of prototypes for the concepts you have developed .	technique
A [MASK] is the best example or representation of a concept .	prototype
For example , for the category of civil disobedience , your [MASK] could be Rosa Parks .	prototype
Her peaceful [MASK] to segregation on a city bus in Montgomery , Alabama , is a recognizable example of civil disobedience .	resistance
Or your [MASK] could be Mohandas Gandhi , sometimes called Mahatma Gandhi (  Mahatma  is an honorific title ) ( Figure 7.3 ) .	prototype
In 1930 , [MASK] Gandhi led a group in peaceful protest against a British tax on salt in India .	Mohandas
[MASK] Gandhi served as a nonviolent force for independence for India while simultaneously demanding that Buddhist , Hindu , Muslim , and Christian leaders  both Indian and British  collaborate peacefully .	Mohandas
Although he was not always successful in preventing violence around him , his [MASK] provides a steadfast example of the civil disobedience prototype ( Constitutional Rights Foundation , 2013 ) .	life
Just as concepts can be abstract or concrete , [MASK] can make a distinction between concepts that are functions of our direct experience with the world and those that are more artificial in nature .	we
Within your industry of interest or area of study , [MASK] are the challenges that create frustration ?	what
Earlier in this chapter , [MASK] discussed Evernote , a company that focuses on expanding our memories by storing and organizing information .	we
In the agriculture industry , [MASK] , weeds , weather conditions , and the challenges of harvesting crops are all ripe for entrepreneurial activities .	insects
The [MASK] toward organic produce has also affected this industry .	move
From an entrepreneurial perspective , what products could [MASK] invent to support both organic farming and the problems of insects that damage or destroy crops ?	you
One new [MASK] to solve this problem combines a vacuum cleaner with an agriculture product .	idea
A bug [MASK] is an example of how using divergent thinking contributed to the solution of removing bugs from crops without using chemicals .	vacuum
However , in the incubation stage , the [MASK] must have come forward as a viable solution .	idea
[MASK] frequently face the challenge of pressure to conform to established habits and patterns within industries .	Entrepreneurs
Often , the entrepreneurial [MASK] includes futuristic ideas that shake up the normal , conventional processes that are grounded in experience over time .	mindset
Tried - and - tested [MASK] and products that have a proven history of success can be a formidable obstacle to new ideas .	processes
A new [MASK] may even appear as impossible or outlandish , perhaps even an embarrassment to the steady and predictable practices established within an industry .	idea
[MASK] can create a dilemma : Do we try something new and unproven that lacks documented research ?	This
Sometimes , [MASK] must disregard our past successes and research to be open to new possibilities for success and failure .	we
An entrepreneurial [MASK] includes creativity , problem - solving skills , and a propensity to innovation . 23	mindset
Open - [MASK] is one characteristic that supports creativity , problem solving , and innovation .	mindedness
Some [MASK] can lead to disruptions within the industry , or even create a new industry .	innovations
One [MASK] of a disruptive technology is Airbnb , a company that threatens the established hotel industry by connecting personal resources to people who desire those resources .	example
[MASK] has become a significant threat to the established hotel industry s business model of building large hotels and renting rooms within those hotels to their customers .	Airbnb
[MASK] has reconfigured that model , and since its 2008 launch , 150 million travelers have taken advantage of 3 million Airbnb listings in more than 191 countries .	Airbnb
[MASK] has raised more than $ 3 billion ( plus a $ 1 billion credit line ) and is considering selling stocks to support significant expansion .	Airbnb
The [MASK] of Airbnb is approximately $ 30 billion .	value
The hotel [MASK] recognized Airbnb as a threat , and in 2016 , began a campaign to create legislation to rein in Airbnb s growth and popularity .	industry
From the hotel industry s perspective , [MASK] is not playing by the same rules .	Airbnb
[MASK] is the definition of disruptive technology , the focus on creating a new idea or process that negates or challenges established process or products . 24	This
Sometimes disruptive [MASK] result from not listening to customers .	technologies
[MASK] do nt always know what they want .	Customers
Customer [MASK] might need to be redefined by the entrepreneurial team on the basis of better models , knowing when to invest in developing lower - performance products that promise lower margins while still satisfying the need , and knowing when to pursue small markets at the expense of larger or established markets .	groups
Basically , disruptive [MASK] occur through identifying new and valuable processes and products .	technologies
The [MASK] of Airbnb recognized that some people have unused resources , bedrooms , that other people need .	founders
[MASK] can apply this idea to other unused resources such as vehicles and motor homes .	We
[MASK] see this model reproduced in short - term car rental and bike - sharing programs .	We
So far , [MASK] have covered how evolutionary ethics relates to the question what we ought to do and why we are moral in the first place .	we
A related [MASK] of questions about ethics are metaethical questions , which concern the meaning of moral terms , our ways of gaining knowledge of moral facts , and the nature of the moral facts .	set
In other words , apart from thinking about how we ought to live , and where our moral sense comes from , [MASK] can also ask what it means to affirm a particular answer to that question , how we could come to know the answer , and whether the answer would be a matter of fact or more like an opinion .	we
Many [MASK] and articles in moral philosophy start with the observation that moral judgments seem to be objectively true and the assumption that this is how non-philosophers also think about morality .	books
For example , [MASK] Smith writes :	Michael
[MASK] seem to think moral questions have correct answers ; that the correct answers are made correct by objective moral facts ; that moral facts are wholly determined by circumstances ; and that , by engaging in moral conversation and argument , we can discover what these objective facts are .	We
But as we have seen above , evolutionary [MASK] explains why we would think that moral judgments are objective .	theory
The [MASK] Michael Ruse takes this to show that the apparent objectivity of morality is something like an  illusion  foisted on us by our genes ( Ruse [ 1986 ] 1998 , 253 ) .	philosopher
Of course , even if Ruse is correct , [MASK] does not show that moral judgments are not objective , but it can make us think whether the objectivity of morality really has to be explained , as many philosophers assume .	this
[MASK] has also argued that an evolutionary account of morality suggests that there are no moral facts in the first place .	Ruse
If moral facts are explanatorily redundant , indeed , moral [MASK] ( those who believe there are mind - independent , objective facts about morality , as discussed in Chapter 1 ) need to say why we should still suppose that moral facts do exist .	realists
Interestingly , Ruse s methodological [MASK] leads him to embrace a view that goes against the metaphysical naturalist position that moral facts exist .	naturalism
Relatedly , [MASK] Street , for example , argues that evolutionary explanations of morality show that moral realism is probably false .	Sharon
The [MASK] of moral realism that Street has in mind is the view that moral properties exist as objective features of the world ( to wit , whether stealing is wrong is independent of whether anyone thinks or feels that stealing is wrong ) .	kind
[MASK] starts with the premise that our moral judgments are influenced by evolutionary forces .	Street
This [MASK] , Street claims , gives rise to a dilemma for moral realists concerning the relation of the evolutionary forces that influenced our moral judgments and the moral facts claimed to exist by moral realists .	fact
If there is no relation between the evolutionary forces and the moral facts , then [MASK] would be an astonishing coincidence if many of our moral judgments were true .	it
In light of the coincidence , [MASK] have no reason to assume that our moral judgments are true  an unpalatable conclusion for realists .	we
So , [MASK] should reject moral realism .	we
Street s [MASK] illustrates how evolutionary theory can be used to make a case about which metaethical theories we should adopt .	argument
Both Ruse s and Street s [MASK] rely on the idea that we should only accept that something exists if it plays an indispensable explanatory role and there are means to resist these arguments . [ 12 ]	arguments
Both [MASK] , as presented here , rely on the correctness of the evolutionary explanation of morality they convey .	arguments
In the next section , [MASK] turn to the relevance of evolutionary ethics for moral epistemology .	we
Can [MASK] have Justified Moral Beliefs ?	We
[MASK] would seem like an incredible coincidence if the realists were right that our moral judgments are nonetheless true .	It
[MASK] claims that such a coincidence would be too much to believe .	Street
But [MASK] is the problem , exactly , with having beliefs that are only coincidentally true ?	what
Depending on how we understand  coincidence ,  my [MASK] that there is a bird outside my window is coincidentally true because had I looked a little later , the bird would have flown away already .	belief
Accidentally true [MASK] do not seem problematic in every case .	beliefs
The [MASK] Richard Joyce argues that the problem has to do with the sensitivity of our moral beliefs to the moral facts ( Joyce 2006 ) .	philosopher
Given that our moral beliefs are influenced by evolutionary forces , and not by the moral facts , our moral [MASK] would be the same even if the moral facts would change .	beliefs
But because we should not hold on to such insensitive beliefs , evolutionary [MASK] of morality show that our moral beliefs are unjustified ( because they are not sensitive ) .	explanations
[MASK] is not clear , however , whether and why evolutionary explanations of morality reveal something about our moral beliefs that is particularly troubling from an epistemological perspective .	It
The [MASK] of evolutionary ethics on epistemological questions depends on these deeper questions about epistemology . [ 13 ]	impact
Evolutionary [MASK] of morality , however , provide us with a useful starting point for thinking about these questions .	explanations
Evolutionary [MASK] has helped us to get a much clearer sense of where the human moral sense is coming from .	ethics
While this is a far cry from revealing to us what we ought to do , the research [MASK] seems full of promise nonetheless .	program
Once we get into the details , [MASK] can see that it also raises deep theoretical questions about evolutionary explanations , the relation of descriptive and normative claims , the epistemology of justification and truth , and the general viability of naturalism in ethics .	we
[MASK] left to wonder , then , but with some ideas about where to get our answers .	Much
How do different [MASK] of motivation affect my learning ?	types
How can [MASK] apply the Uses and Gratification Theory to make decisions about my learning ?	I
How do [MASK] prevent negative bias from hindering learning ?	I
In this section , [MASK] will continue to increase your ability as an informed learner .	you
Here [MASK] will explore how much of an influence motivation has on learning , as well as how to use motivation to purposefully take an active role in any learning activity .	you
Rather than passively attempting to absorb new information , [MASK] will learn how to make conscious decisions about the methods of learning you will use ( based on what you intend to do with the information ) , how you will select and use learning materials that are appropriate for your needs , and how persistent you will be in the learning activity .	you
[MASK] will find that each of these is a strong tool that will enable you to engage with learning material in a way that not only suits your needs , but also gives you ownership over your own learning processes .	You
While much of this chapter will cover very specific aspects about the act of learning , in this section , [MASK] will present different information that may at first seem unrelated .	we
Some [MASK] would consider it more of a personal outlook than a learning practice , and yet it has a significant influence on the ability to learn .	people
U.S. Army [MASK] and captain of the U.S. Invictus team , Will Reynolds , races to the finish line .	veteran
The [MASK] showed that grit and perseverance were better predictors of academic success and achievement than talent or IQ .	study
In a 2007 study [MASK] and colleagues found that individuals with high grit were able to maintain motivation in learning tasks despite failures .	Duckworth
The [MASK] examined a cross section of learning environments , such as GPA scores in Ivy League universities , dropout rates at West Point , rankings in the National Spelling Bee , and general educational attainment for adults .	study
What the results showed was that [MASK] and perseverance were better predictors of academic success and achievement than talent or IQ .	grit
The [MASK] of grit is an easy one to dismiss as something taken for granted .	concept
In our culture , [MASK] have a number of sayings and aphorisms that capture the essence of grit :  If at first you do not succeed , try , try again ,  or the famous quote by Thomas Edison :  Genius is one percent inspiration , ninety - nine percent perspiration . 	we
The problem is [MASK] all understand the concept , but actually applying it takes work .	we
If the task we are trying to complete is a difficult one , [MASK] can take a lot of work .	it
In your first attempt at studying [MASK] simply reread the chapters of your textbook covered in the exam .	you
[MASK] find that while this reinforces some of the knowledge you have gained , it does not ensure you have all the information you will need to do well on the test .	You
[MASK] know that if you simply read the chapters yet again , there is no guarantee you are going to be any more successful .	You
[MASK] determine that you need to find a different approach .	You
In other words , your first [MASK] was not a complete failure , but it did not achieve the end goal , so you try again with a different method .	attempt
On your second try , [MASK] copy down all of the main points onto a piece of paper using the section headlines from the chapters .	you
After a short break [MASK] come back to your list and write down a summary of what you know about each item on your list .	you
[MASK] accomplishes two things : first , you are able to immediately spot areas where you need to learn more , and second , you can check your summaries against the text to make certain what you know is correct and adequate .	This
In this example , while you may not have yet achieved complete success , [MASK] will have learned what you need to do next .	you
In true grit fashion , for your next try , [MASK] study those items on your list where you found you needed a bit more information , and then you go through your list again .	you
This time [MASK] are able to write down summaries of all the important points , and you are confident you have the knowledge you need to do well on the exam .	you
After this , [MASK] still do not stop , but instead you change your approach to use other methods that keep what you have learned fresh in your mind .	you
By the end of this section , [MASK] will be able to :	you
Some [MASK] believe that between nine and fifteen thousand years ago , a land bridge existed between Asia and North America that we now call Beringia .	scholars
The first [MASK] of what would be named the Americas migrated across this bridge in search of food .	inhabitants
When the glaciers melted , [MASK] engulfed Beringia , and the Bering Strait was formed .	water
Later [MASK] came by boat across the narrow strait .	settlers
( The [MASK] that Asians and American Indians share genetic markers on a Y chromosome lends credibility to this migration theory . )	fact
Continually moving southward , the [MASK] eventually populated both North and South America , creating unique cultures that ranged from the highly complex and urban Aztec civilization in what is now Mexico City to the woodland tribes of eastern North America .	settlers
Recent [MASK] along the west coast of South America suggests that migrant populations may have traveled down this coast by water as well as by land .	research
[MASK] believe that about ten thousand years ago , humans also began the domestication of plants and animals , adding agriculture as a means of sustenance to hunting and gathering techniques .	Researchers
With this agricultural revolution , and the more abundant and reliable food supplies it brought , [MASK] grew and people were able to develop a more settled way of life , building permanent settlements .	populations
Nowhere in the Americas was [MASK] more obvious than in Mesoamerica ( Figure 1.3 ) .	this
This [MASK] shows the extent of the major civilizations of the Western Hemisphere .	map
In South America , early [MASK] developed along the coast because the high Andes and the inhospitable Amazon Basin made the interior of the continent less favorable for settlement .	civilizations
[MASK] is the geographic area stretching from north of Panama up to the desert of central Mexico .	Mesoamerica
Although marked by great topographic , linguistic , and cultural diversity , this [MASK] cradled a number of civilizations with similar characteristics .	region
[MASK] were polytheistic ; their gods possessed both male and female traits and demanded blood sacrifices of enemies taken in battle or ritual bloodletting .	Mesoamericans
[MASK] , or maize , domesticated by 5000 BCE , formed the basis of their diet .	Corn
[MASK] developed a mathematical system , built huge edifices , and devised a calendar that accurately predicted eclipses and solstices and that priest - astronomers used to direct the planting and harvesting of crops .	They
Most important for our knowledge of these peoples , [MASK] created the only known written language in the Western Hemisphere ; researchers have made much progress in interpreting the inscriptions on their temples and pyramids .	they
Though the area had no overarching political structure , [MASK] over long distances helped diffuse culture .	trade
[MASK] made of obsidian , jewelry crafted from jade , feathers woven into clothing and ornaments , and cacao beans that were whipped into a chocolate drink formed the basis of commerce .	Weapons
The [MASK] of Mesoamerican cultures was the Olmec civilization .	mother
Flourishing along the hot Gulf Coast of Mexico from about 1200 to about 400 BCE , the [MASK] produced a number of major works of art , architecture , pottery , and sculpture .	Olmec
The [MASK] built aqueducts to transport water into their cities and irrigate their fields .	Olmec
[MASK] grew maize , squash , beans , and tomatoes .	They
[MASK] also bred small domesticated dogs which , along with fish , provided their protein .	They
Although no one knows what happened to the Olmec after about 400 BCE , in part because the jungle reclaimed many of their cities , their [MASK] was the base upon which the Maya and the Aztec built .	culture
The [MASK] also developed a system of trade throughout Mesoamerica , giving rise to an elite class .	Olmec
The [MASK] carved heads from giant boulders that ranged from four to eleven feet in height and could weigh up to fifty tons .	Olmec
All these [MASK] have flat noses , slightly crossed eyes , and large lips .	figures
After the decline of the Olmec , a [MASK] rose in the fertile central highlands of Mesoamerica .	city
Large - scale [MASK] and the resultant abundance of food allowed time for people to develop special trades and skills other than farming .	agriculture
[MASK] constructed over twenty - two hundred apartment compounds for multiple families , as well as more than a hundred temples .	Builders
The [MASK] was also the center for trade , which extended to settlements on Mesoamerica s Gulf Coast .	city
The [MASK] were one Mesoamerican culture that had strong ties to Teotihuacan .	Maya
The Maya s architectural and mathematical [MASK] were significant .	contributions
Flourishing from roughly 2000 BCE to 900 CE in what is now Mexico , Belize , Honduras , and Guatemala , the [MASK] perfected the calendar and written language the Olmec had begun .	Maya
[MASK] devised a written mathematical system to record crop yields and the size of the population , and to assist in trade .	They
Surrounded by farms relying on primitive agriculture , [MASK] built the city - states of Copan , Tikal , and Chichen Itza along their major trade routes , as well as temples , statues of gods , pyramids , and astronomical observatories ( Figure 1.5 ) .	they
However , because of poor soil and a drought that lasted nearly two centuries , their [MASK] declined by about 900 CE and they abandoned their large population centers .	civilization
[MASK] Castillo , located at Chichen Itza in the eastern Yucatn peninsula , served as a temple for the god Kukulkan .	El
Each [MASK] contains ninety - one steps to the top .	side
When counting the top platform , the total [MASK] of stairs is three hundred and sixty - five , the number of days in a year .	number
The [MASK] found little organized resistance among the weakened Maya upon their arrival in the 1520s .	Spanish
However , [MASK] did find Mayan history , in the form of glyphs , or pictures representing words , recorded in folding books called codices ( the singular is codex ) .	they
In 1562 , [MASK] Diego de Landa , who feared the converted natives had reverted to their traditional religious practices , collected and burned every codex he could find .	Bishop
Today only a [MASK] survive .	few
1. [MASK] of the following Indian peoples built homes in cliff dwellings that still exist ?	Which
2. Which [MASK] developed the first writing system in the Western Hemisphere ?	culture
Despite how much humans have in common , cultural [MASK] are far more prevalent than cultural universals .	differences
For example , while all cultures have language , [MASK] of particular language structures and conversational etiquette reveal tremendous differences .	analysis
North [MASK] keep more distance and maintain a large  personal space . 	Americans
Even [MASK] as simple as eating and drinking varies greatly from culture to culture .	something
If your professor comes into an early morning class holding a mug of liquid , what do [MASK] assume she is drinking ?	you
The [MASK] cuisines vary across cultures fascinates many people .	way
Some [MASK] pride themselves on their willingness to try unfamiliar foods , like celebrated food writer Anthony Bourdain , while others return home expressing gratitude for their native culture s fare .	travelers
Often , [MASK] in the United States express disgust at other cultures  cuisine and think that it s gross to eat meat from a dog or guinea pig , for example , while they do nt question their own habit of eating cows or pigs .	people
Such [MASK] are an example of ethnocentrism , or evaluating and judging another culture based on how it compares to one s own cultural norms .	attitudes
[MASK] , as sociologist William Graham Sumner ( 1906 ) described the term , involves a belief or attitude that one s own culture is better than all others .	Ethnocentrism
Almost [MASK] is a little bit ethnocentric .	everyone
For example , [MASK] tend to say that people from England drive on the  wrong  side of the road , rather than on the  other  side .	Americans
[MASK] might question , " Far east of where ? "	One
A high [MASK] of appreciation for one s own culture can be healthy ; a shared sense of community pride , for example , connects people in a society .	level
But [MASK] can lead to disdain or dislike for other cultures and could cause misunderstanding and conflict .	ethnocentrism
[MASK] with the best intentions sometimes travel to a society to  help  its people , because they see them as uneducated or backward - essentially inferior .	People
In reality , these [MASK] are guilty of cultural imperialism , the deliberate imposition of one s own cultural values on another culture .	travelers
European [MASK] often viewed the people in the lands they colonized as uncultured savages who were in need of European governance , dress , religion , and other cultural practices .	colonizers
A more modern [MASK] of cultural imperialism may include the work of international aid agencies who introduce agricultural methods and plant species from developed countries while overlooking indigenous varieties and agricultural approaches that are better suited to the particular region .	example
[MASK] can be so strong that when confronted with all of the differences of a new culture , one may experience disorientation and frustration .	Ethnocentrism
In sociology , [MASK] call this culture shock .	we
A [MASK] from Chicago might find the nightly silence of rural Montana unsettling , not peaceful .	traveler
Perhaps the Chicago [MASK] was initially captivated with Montana s quiet beauty and the Chinese student was originally excited to see a U.S. - style classroom firsthand .	traveler
But as they experience unanticipated differences from their own culture , their [MASK] gives way to discomfort and doubts about how to behave appropriately in the new situation .	excitement
Eventually , as people learn more about a culture , [MASK] recover from culture shock .	they
Culture [MASK] may appear because people are nt always expecting cultural differences .	shock
[MASK] Ken Barger ( 1971 ) discovered this when he conducted a participatory observation in an Inuit community in the Canadian Arctic .	Anthropologist
Originally from Indiana , [MASK] hesitated when invited to join a local snowshoe race .	Barger
[MASK] knew he d never hold his own against these experts .	He
Sure enough , [MASK] finished last , to his mortification .	he
But the tribal [MASK] congratulated him , saying ,  You really tried ! 	members
In Barger s own culture , [MASK] had learned to value victory .	he
Over the course of his stay , [MASK] participated in caribou hunts , learned how to take shelter in winter storms , and sometimes went days with little or no food to share among tribal members .	Barger
During his time with the Inuit tribe , [MASK] learned to engage in cultural relativism .	Barger
Cultural [MASK] is the practice of assessing a culture by its own standards rather than viewing it through the lens of one s own culture .	relativism
Even the most culturally relativist [MASK] from egalitarian societies  ones in which women have political rights and control over their own bodies  would question whether the widespread practice of female genital mutilation in countries such as Ethiopia and Sudan should be accepted as a part of cultural tradition .	people
[MASK] attempting to engage in cultural relativism , then , may struggle to reconcile aspects of their own culture with aspects of a culture that they are studying .	Sociologists
Sometimes when people attempt to rectify feelings of ethnocentrism and develop cultural relativism , [MASK] swing too far to the other end of the spectrum .	they
[MASK] is the opposite of ethnocentrism , and refers to the belief that another culture is superior to one s own .	Xenocentrism
( The Greek root [MASK] xeno , pronounced  ZEE-no ,  means  stranger  or  foreign guest .  )	word
By the end of this section , [MASK] will be able to :	you
[MASK] preferred to think that it is space and time that are affected by the presence of a large mass ; light beams , and everything else that travels through space and time , then find their paths affected .	Einstein
[MASK] always follows the shortest path  but that path may not always be straight .	Light
This [MASK] is true for human travel on the curved surface of planet Earth , as well .	idea
Since an airplane ca nt go through the solid body of the Earth , the shortest [MASK] is not a straight line but the arc of a great circle .	distance
[MASK] explain that your dorm is at 6400 College Avenue , a street that runs in the left - right direction on a map of your town ; you are on the fifth floor , which tells where you are in the up - down direction ; and you are the sixth room back from the elevator , which tells where you are in the forward - backward direction .	You
Then [MASK] explain that the fire broke out at 6:23 p.m. ( but was soon brought under control ) , which specifies the event in time .	you
[MASK] considered space and time to be completely independent , and that continued to be the accepted view until the beginning of the twentieth century .	Newton
But [MASK] showed that there is an intimate connection between space and time , and that only by considering the two together  in what we call spacetime  can we build up a correct picture of the physical world .	Einstein
[MASK] examine spacetime a bit more closely in the next subsection .	We
The gist of Einstein s general theory is that the [MASK] of matter curves or warps the fabric of spacetime .	presence
When something else  a beam of light , an electron , or the starship Enterprise  enters such a region of distorted spacetime , its [MASK] will be different from what it would have been in the absence of the matter .	path
As American physicist John Wheeler summarized it :  [MASK] tells spacetime how to curve ; spacetime tells matter how to move . 	Matter
The [MASK] of distortion in spacetime depends on the mass of material that is involved and on how concentrated and compact it is .	amount
Terrestrial [MASK] , such as the book you are reading , have far too little mass to introduce any significant distortion .	objects
Newton s [MASK] of gravity is just fine for building bridges , skyscrapers , or amusement park rides .	view
General [MASK] does , however , have some practical applications .	relativity
The [MASK] ( Global Positioning System ) in every smartphone can tell you where you are within 5 to 10 meters only because the effects of general and special relativity on the GPS satellites in orbit around the Earth are taken into account .	GPS
Unlike a book or your roommate , [MASK] produce measurable distortions in spacetime .	stars
A white [MASK] , with its stronger surface gravity , produces more distortion just above its surface than does a red giant with the same mass .	dwarf
So , you see , [MASK] are eventually going to talk about collapsing stars again , but not before discussing Einstein s ideas ( and the evidence for them ) in more detail .	we
How can [MASK] understand the distortion of spacetime by the presence of some ( significant ) amount of mass ?	we
[MASK] may have seen maps of New York City that squeeze the full three dimensions of this towering metropolis onto a flat sheet of paper and still have enough information so tourists will not get lost .	You
[MASK] 24.7 , for example , shows the progress of a motorist driving east on a stretch of road in Kansas where the countryside is absolutely flat .	Figure
Since our motorist is traveling only in the east - west direction and the terrain is flat , [MASK] can ignore the other two dimensions of space .	we
From A to B [MASK] drove at a uniform speed ; unfortunately , it was too fast a uniform speed and a police car spotted him .	he
From B to C [MASK] stopped to receive his ticket and made no progress through space , only through time .	he
From C to D [MASK] drove more slowly because the police car was behind him .	he
This [MASK] shows the progress of a motorist traveling east across the flat Kansas landscape .	diagram
In this case , [MASK] will ( in our imaginations ) use a rubber sheet that can stretch or warp if we put objects on it .	we
To complete the analogy , [MASK] need something that normally travels in a straight line ( as light does ) .	we
[MASK] begin with just the rubber sheet and the ant , simulating empty space with no mass in it .	We
[MASK] put the ant on one side of the sheet and it walks in a beautiful straight line over to the other side ( Figure 24.8 ) .	We
[MASK] next put a small grain of sand on the rubber sheet .	We
The [MASK] does distort the sheet a tiny bit , but this is not a distortion that we or the ant can measure .	sand
If we send the ant so it goes close to , but not on top of , the sand grain , [MASK] has little trouble continuing to walk in a straight line .	it
Now [MASK] grab something with a little more mass  say , a small pebble .	we
[MASK] bends or distorts the sheet just a bit around its position .	It
If we send the ant into this region , [MASK] finds its path slightly altered by the distortion of the sheet .	it
The [MASK] is not large , but if we follow the ant s path carefully , we notice it deviating slightly from a straight line .	distortion
The [MASK] gets more noticeable as we increase the mass of the object that we put on the sheet .	effect
Such a heavy [MASK] distorts or warps the rubber sheet very effectively , putting a good sag in it .	object
From our point of view , [MASK] can see that the sheet near the paperweight is no longer straight .	we
The common [MASK] of location are quartiles and percentiles .	measures
[MASK] are special percentiles .	Quartiles
The first [MASK] , Q 1 , is the same as the 25th percentile , and the third quartile , Q 3 , is the same as the 75th percentile .	quartile
To calculate quartiles and percentiles , [MASK] must order the data from smallest to largest .	you
[MASK] divide ordered data into quarters .	Quartiles
[MASK] divide ordered data into hundredths .	Percentiles
So , [MASK] mean the data is divided into 100 sections .	percentiles
[MASK] means that 90 percent of test scores are the same as or less than your score and that 10 percent of the test scores are the same as or greater than your test score .	It
[MASK] are useful for comparing values .	Percentiles
For this reason , [MASK] and colleges use percentiles extensively .	universities
One [MASK] in which colleges and universities use percentiles is when SAT results are used to determine a minimum testing score that will be used as an acceptance factor .	instance
[MASK] translates into a score of at least 1220 .	That
Therefore , if you were to say that 90 percent of the test scores are less , and not the same or less , than your score , [MASK] would be acceptable because removing one particular data value is not significant .	it
The [MASK] is a number that measures the center of the data .	median
[MASK] can think of the median as the middle value , but it does not actually have to be one of the observed values .	You
[MASK] is a number that separates ordered data into halves .	It
Half the [MASK] are the same number or smaller than the median , and half the values are the same number or larger .	values
When a data set has an even number of data values , the [MASK] is equal to the average of the two middle values when the data are arranged in ascending order ( least to greatest ) .	median
When a data set has an odd number of data values , the [MASK] is equal to the middle value when the data are arranged in ascending order .	median
Since there are 14 observations ( an even number of data values ) , the [MASK] is between the seventh value , 6.8 , and the eighth value , 7.2 .	median
( [MASK] + 7.2 ) / 2 = 7	6.8
The [MASK] is seven .	median
[MASK] of the values are smaller than seven and half of the values are larger than seven .	Half
[MASK] are numbers that separate the data into quarters .	Quartiles
[MASK] may or may not be part of the data .	Quartiles
The first [MASK] , Q 1 , is the middle value of the lower half of the data , and the third quartile , Q 3 , is the middle value , or median , of the upper half of the data .	quartile
The data [MASK] has an even number of values ( 14 data values ) , so the median will be the average of the two middle values ( the average of 6.8 and 7.2 ) , which is calculated as ( 6.8 + 7.2 ) / 2 and equals 7 .	set
So , the [MASK] , or second quartile ( Q 2 ) , is 7 .	median
The first [MASK] is the median of the lower half of the data , so if we divide the data into seven values in the lower half and seven values in the upper half , we can see that we have an odd number of values in the lower half .	quartile
Thus , the [MASK] of the lower half , or the first quartile ( Q 1 ) will be the middle value , or 2 .	median
Using the same procedure , [MASK] can see that the median of the upper half , or the third quartile ( Q 3 ) will be the middle value of the upper half , or 9 .	we
The interquartile [MASK] is a number that indicates the spread of the middle half , or the middle 50 percent of the data .	range
[MASK] is the difference between the third quartile ( Q 3 ) and the first quartile ( Q 1 )	It
[MASK] = Q 3  Q 1 .	IQR
The [MASK] can help to determine potential outliers .	IQR
Potential [MASK] always require further investigation .	outliers
A potential [MASK] is a data point that is significantly different from the other data points .	outlier
These special data [MASK] may be errors or some kind of abnormality , or they may be a key to understanding the data .	points
[MASK] are in dollars .	Prices
The following [MASK] are in dollars .	salaries
In the example above , [MASK] just saw the calculation of the median , first quartile , and third quartile .	you
These three [MASK] are part of the five number summary .	values
The other two [MASK] are the minimum value ( or min ) and the maximum value ( or max ) .	values

The Chatnam [MASK] ( Rekohu in the indigenous Moriori language ) are the eastern - most settled islands in New Zealand .	Islands
The [MASK] are in their own time zone , 45 minutes ahead of New Zealand time ;	islands
the International Date [MASK] jogs eastward to keep them on the same calendar day as the rest of New Zealand .	Line
The [MASK] lie 860 km east of Christchurch , in the middle of the " Roaring Forties " .	islands
Steeped in culture and history , these [MASK] are on the very edge of civilisation .	islands
The Chatham [MASK] consist of the main island , Chatham Island itself , with a population of 600 , smaller Pitt Island with about 40 inhabitants , and a number of rocky outcrops .	Islands
The [MASK] are volcanic in origin and have a unique and sensitive habitat that supports many rare and endangered species .	islands
The original [MASK] of the islands are the Moriori , who were descended from the Maori of mainland New Zealand , but who developed their own culture and variant of the language .	people
In 1835 Maori [MASK] from the mainland arrived , massacred and enslaved the Moriori .	settlers
The only [MASK] for visitors to travel to the Chathams is via scheduled or chartered air service .	way
Air [MASK] fly 5 days per week , from either Christchurch , Auckland or Wellington and , seasonally , from Napier .	Chathams
[MASK] should book or ensure accommodation before you board a flight for the Chathams , as during the popular months of the tourism season , between October and April , accommodation can be severely limited .	You
Although flying to the Chathams and back is not cheap , [MASK] is worth it .	it
Even the mainland school [MASK] that fly there for school camps , and choose to stay at Kopinga Marae [ 1 ] get value for money by chartering a flight one way .	groups
Anyway , [MASK] do n't have a choice on how you get there , unless you happen to own an aeroplane .	you
However , when you get off that aeroplane , if you have n't pre-organised transport , [MASK] will have to walk , and it is a long way into town .	you
The only scheduled shipping [MASK] to the Chatham Islands remains the Black Robin Freighters " Rangatira " , an antiquated , slow and small coastal trading vessel .	service
This [MASK] has serviced the islands for many years , but does not carry passengers .	boat
Freight [MASK] on the Rangatira appear to be flexible and subject to change .	charges
[MASK] can call at the Chathams and there are a number of " safe " harbours for shelter if the need arises .	Vessels
Chatham [MASK] have a range of nice rental vans available as well and they provide pretty good service for both visitors and locals .	Motors
[MASK] of the lodge can meander around either a short easy walk , or take the longer 2 hr return walk out onto the spectacular beach .	Guests
[MASK] is free to Lodge guests .	Access
One of only two National Historic Scenic Reserves in New Zealand ( the other is the Waitangi Treaty Grounds ) , [MASK] is a special place , and somewhere that you will want to tell others about .	Hapupu
Spiritually and culturally important to Moriori , [MASK] holds the last known concentration of momori - rakau , or tree carvings done by the ancestors of today 's Moriori .	it
One of the most scenicly attractive ports in the whole of New Zealand , [MASK] Hutt boasts an incredibly sheltered little harbour , with picturesque views and safe anchorage in all weather .	Port
Historically important and economically crucial for these islands today , [MASK] Hutt is the ideal location for a short browse around and a mecca for those photography buffs [ 2 ] .	Port
If you could define a place that will remind you of your visit to the Chathams , then this very special [MASK] will be at the top of your list .	place
Opened in 2005 , [MASK] is the official meeting place of Te Imi Moriori .	Kopinga
Adorned with contemporary Moriori carvings and traditional taonga ( treasures ) , the [MASK] is a magnificent , tasteful and contemporary testament to the ancestors of Te Imi Moriori .	marae
School - [MASK] At Kopinga Marae [ 3 ] also utilise this wonderful national treasure for hosting visiting school groups .	Camps
[MASK] Horomona Rehe was the last known full - blooded Moriori and he passed away in 1933 .	Tame
[MASK] was however , not the last Moriori .	He
His own [MASK] and the descendants of other Moriori live on today .	descendants
[MASK] is a culturally diverse city on the shores of Lake Erie , one of the Great Lakes , in Cuyahoga County , Ohio , USA .	Cleveland
Recreational , cultural and educational [MASK] are abundant throughout Northeast Ohio .	opportunities
[MASK] 'll find world - class museums and cultural events , professional sports and amusement parks , and the most golf courses per capita in the United States .	You
Places Rated [MASK] ranks the area second in recreational options out of 354 US metro areas .	Almanac
Plus , this [MASK] ranks fifth in the nation in number of major cultural resources per one million residents .	region
[MASK] is the urban center of Northeast Ohio , the 15th largest combined metropolitan area in the United States .	Cleveland
Like most U.S. cities , [MASK] proper began to lose population to suburban areas in the 1960s and 1970s .	Cleveland
However , in the mid-1980s , [MASK] earned the nickname the " Comeback City " as the urban core experienced a dramatic revitalization process that continues today .	Cleveland
As its " comeback " has continued , the official [MASK] is now the New American City as Cleveland has rightfully earned the reputation as a model of effective public - private partnership for urban planning .	moniker
Despite the common perception that Cleveland is an industrial town , just beyond the automotive and steel plants , a clean and beautiful [MASK] rises at the mouth of the Cuyahoga River on the southern shore of Lake Erie ( often marvelled over by visitors who are surprised you ca n't see the other side , i.e. , Canada ) .	downtown
Like other cities in the so - called " rust belt  , [MASK] has endured growing pains as it makes its transition from a manufacturing - based economy .	Cleveland
While Cleveland continues to play a leading role in building the U.S. industrial base , [MASK] has also developed economic prowess in the fields of health care , law , finance , insurance , real estate development , and professional services .	it
Another thing non-locals do n't often realize is that Cleveland 's long [MASK] of industrial wealth has left it chock full of cultural riches as well as the beginnings of a " sustainable city " movement .	history
For decades , the [MASK] has boasted of : a " Big Five " orchestra ( The Cleveland Orchestra ) , the second largest performing arts center in the U.S. ( Playhouse Square Center ) , a world - renowned art museum ( The Cleveland Museum of Art ) , the nation 's first health museum ( HealthSpace Cleveland ) , R&D hub of the aerospace and aviation industry ( the NASA Glenn Research & Visitors Center ) and a number of other first - rate attractions ( too many to mention here - read on ) .	city
During its " comeback " years , [MASK] has added : the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum , the Great Lakes Science Center with Omnimax theatre , and four new sports facilities in the downtown area - Progressive Field ( Still known as " The Jake " after a recent corporate name change ) for the Major League Baseball Indians , QuickenLoans Arena ( " The Q " ) for the NBA Cavaliers , Cleveland Browns Stadium for the NFL Browns and the Wolstein Center for the Cleveland State University Vikings basketball team .	Cleveland
A tourist visa [MASK] ( visa de tarjeta del turista ) is necessary for travelers from most nations .	card
This [MASK] , which is really little more than a piece of paper on which you list your vital statistics , costs between 15 - 25 CUC ( or  15 - 25 ) , depending on where purchased .	visa
[MASK] is usually valid for 30 days and can be extended once for another 30 days at any immigration office in Cuba ( for 25 CUC ) - beyond this you would need a flight out of Cuba within the extended visa period .	It
[MASK] are the exception , getting 90 days on arrival and can apply for a 90 day extension .	Canadians
Your [MASK] needs to be valid at least six months past the end of your planned return .	passport
Canadian [MASK] must be valid for at least one month beyond the date of expected departure ( [ 2 ] ) .	passports
Some times , the [MASK] provides these at the airport , however check first that this is the case .	airline
If you can not go to the Cuban Consulate [MASK] may consider using VisaCuba ( [ 3 ] ) because it may be cheaper .	you
Through them [MASK] may cost  20 in total per person .	it
If you apply in person to the Cuban Consulate , [MASK] get the visa straight away .	you
Travel [MASK] may often offer cheaper and quicker services though .	agencies
Regular [MASK] who renew their 30 day visa are eligible to depart the country ( to any destination ) and return immediately enjoying a further 60 days ( 30 days plus a 30 day extension ) .	tourists
If you want to stay with friends or family in Cuba [MASK] have to go with your intended host within two days after arrival to a migration office and pay 40 CUC for a 30 days family visa .	you
( The [MASK] of the previous sentence is unknown .	source
Aeromexico [MASK] at Cancun airport claim that only citizens of China and Russia need no visa .	staff
[MASK] will run into significant difficulties if you do not have enough cash to pay this tax when leaving the country .	You
An [MASK] and currency exchange are available at Havana airport , but these facilities are not as reliable in Cuba as in other places .	ATM
Cuban [MASK] can be strict , though they sometimes go easy on tourists .	customs
[MASK] Lee is a city in Bergen County .	Fort
[MASK] Lee is a small town but is piled high with apartment buildings .	Fort
The New York City [MASK] and 4th of July fireworks are spectacular over the river .	skyline
Although it is highly built up , [MASK] Lee also houses many playing fields and recreational parks as well as bike and running trails .	Fort
And although there is a great deal of vehicle traffic to and from the George Washington Bridge , which connects Fort Lee with Manhattan , [MASK] of the largest perks of this town is the walking access to many restaurants , convenience stores and mass transit , in the form of buses and vans that frequently run across the bridge and up and down major streets .	one
[MASK] Lee is the first town on the New Jersey side of the bridge .	Fort
The nearest [MASK] to Fort Lee are Newark Airport , LaGuardia Airport , Teterboro ( general aviation only ) , JFK and Westchester County Airport .	airports
[MASK] and new meet in Fort Lee , as the Good Shepherd Episcopalian Church is dwarfed by a residential highrise immediately behind it	Old
Most [MASK] choose cars , but if headed to a central area , such as Main Street , it is best to drive there , park in a municipal parking lot , and walk around from there .	people
If you are planning on being somewhere at a certain time , [MASK] might suggest leaving a good 10 to 15 minutes to escape local traffic before hitting any major roadways .	one
The Visitors ' [MASK] provides information on the role of Fort Lee in the War .	Center
Audio - visual [MASK] , detailed exhibits , gives visitors a sense of what this town was like centuries ago .	displays
[MASK] Lee also has a great community center open to all borough residents .	Fort
The community [MASK] has dance , yoga , and other exercise classes , offers open gym hours for basketball or other recreation .	center
Store [MASK] : Mon - Fri 08:30 am - 7 pm , Sat 08:30 am - 06:30 pm , Sun 9 am - 03:00 pm	hours
Main [MASK] is the primary retail section of Fort Lee , and features stores such as Borders and liquor stores , and you can find a deli or drug store on every corner .	Street
Within Fort Lee , the main [MASK] would be its collection of restaurants .	attraction
[MASK] Lee offers international cuisine and is famous for their pizzerias , delis and 24 - hour diners , in addition to its Korean restaurants .	Fort
[MASK] have a warm local atmosphere and taste great .	They
[MASK] , known as Gwadloup in the local creole , and sometimes known as the Butterfly Island ( French : I'ile Papillon ) on account of the shape of two of its major islands , is a group of islands in the eastern Caribbean , and is a French overseas department .	Guadeloupe
( [MASK] can enter most nightclubs with proper clothes , that is , no sneakers , no shorts )	You
From there , [MASK] can look up at the islands La Dsirade , Petite Terre , Marie Galante , Les Saintes , La Dominique but also have a perfect view of the islands Grande Terre and far away Basse Terre .	you
